headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter Simon Property Group 2015 Earnings Call. My name is Lauren, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions]I would now like to turn the conference over to Tom Ward, Vice Pr
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter Simon Property Group 2015 Earnings Call. My name is Lauren, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the conference over to Tom Ward, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lauren. Good morning, everyone. Presenting on today's call is David Simon, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Also on the call are Rick Sokolov, President and Chief Operating Officer; Andy Juster, Chief Financial Officer; and Steven Broadwat
componenttext:
Thank you, Lauren. Good morning, everyone. Presenting on today's call is David Simon, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Also on the call are Rick Sokolov, President and Chief Operating Officer; Andy Juster, Chief Financial Officer; and Steven Broadwater, our Chief Accounting Officer.
Before we begin, a quick reminder that statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 and actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. We refer you to today's press release and our SEC filings for a detailed discussion of forward-looking statements.
Please note that this call includes information that may be accurate only as of today's date. Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included within the press release and the supplemental information in today's Form 8-K filing. Both the press release and the supplemental information are available on our IR website at investors.simon.com.
For our prepared remarks, I'm pleased to introduce David Simon.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. We had strong results to wrap up a great year. We opened, started and completed several new development and redevelopment projects. We successfully executed several Capital Market transaction, extending our average term and reducing our weig
componenttext:
Good morning. We had strong results to wrap up a great year. We opened, started and completed several new development and redevelopment projects. We successfully executed several Capital Market transaction, extending our average term and reducing our weighted interest costs. We continued to achieve strong operating and financial results.
Our full year 2015 FFO per share was $9.86, which beat our initial guidance range of $9.60 to $9.70 a share, even with a net $0.11 loss reported during the year, which was derived from $0.33 loss on extinguishment of debt partially offset by $0.22 gain upon the sale of marketable securities that occurred in the year as well as a $0.12 of negative impact from foreign currency devaluations.
On a comparable basis, excluding the impact from WPG's spinoff in the prior year and the net loss mentioned above, full year FFO increased 11.4% to $9.97 per diluted share. We posted record FFO results once again and have achieved a compound annual FFO growth rate of more than 14% over the last 5 years.
For the fourth quarter, FFO of $2.40 per share included a $0.33 loss on extinguishment of debt and exceeded the consensus estimate by $0.02. On a comparable basis, excluding the loss on the extinguishment of debt in the quarter, FFO per diluted share increased 10.5% year-over-year.
Now let me turn to operating metrics and cash flow. Our malls and Premium Outlets occupancy ended the year at 96.1%. This was 100%, 100 basis points lower than year-end 2014 due to the timing of a lease up of more than 2 million square feet of the new space we brought online this year from expansions and new developments as well as replacing the 1.3 million square feet of space lost due to tenant bankruptcies during the year.
Importantly, we are more than 90% leased on the new space we bought online this year. The timing of the lease up on the remaining space to be leased impacted our year end occupancy by approximately 50 basis points.
By the end of the year, we replaced more than 70% of the space loss for tenant bankruptcies and the remaining space to be leased impacted occupancy by 50 basis points as well. Put the 2 together and that's 100 basis points differential. Leasing activity remains healthy as evidenced by the malls and Premium Outlets recorded leasing spread of $10.63 per foot, an increase of 18% and the basement memorandum was $48.96, which was up more than 4% compared to last year, reflecting strong retailer demand for our locations.
As I mentioned, retailer demand for space remained strong. Retailers who want to grow their business or adding brand extensions and creating new brands and pure player e-tailers went physical locations to increase their revenues. E-tailers who opened bricks and mortar stores experienced increased consumer awareness and subsequently greater organic site traffic and lower customer acquisition costs. We have repeatedly heard from retailers that online sales is directly influenced by the presence of a physical store in that market. When the retailer opens a physical store in the markets, they see their online sales increase and likewise, if they close the store, they see their online sales in that market decline. Successful omni-channel retailers are increasing their buy online and pick up in-store. This functionality not only increases convenience for shoppers but also facilitates incremental purchases and up-sell opportunities when the shopper enters our retail environment.
For 2015, sales per square foot for our mall and Premium Outlets were $620 a foot compared to $619. Comparable sales per square foot for the malls increased 5.7%. We were up a greater amount at the mills and we were down slightly at our tourist-oriented Premium Outlets and up slightly at our non-tourist outlet centers. We have great centers in key tourist locations that generate incredible sales volume and at the envy of the industry. The strong dollar, however, impacted tenant sales at these unique centers, which negatively affected our average rent for the quarter 
I know you all heard about mall traffic decreases. Now let me give some facts based on our internal data across the largest retailer portfolio in the U.S. and not just estimates derived from arbitrary algorithms. Traffic at our malls was flat for the year, including the holiday season. Traffic of our Premium Outlets increased 1.5% for the year and more than 2% for the holidays and traffic at the Mills increased slightly for the year as well.
Up NOI increased 3.7% for the full year 2015 and increased 3.4% for the fourth quarter of 2015. For the fourth quarter, overage rent declined $13 million year-over-year due to the lower sales volumes that I mentioned earlier at our tourist-oriented centers. The lower overage rent impacted our comp NOI for the quarter of approximately 100 basis points. I will strongly remind you, we do not include lease settlement income, new acquisitions or the impact of recently redeveloped or expanded centers in our comp NOI -- comp NOI numbers.
Total NOI from our consolidated and unconsolidated properties increased more than 7% to $5.8 billion in 2015. That was on top of 6.7% growth in 2014 and this includes any NOI contribution from Kl√©pierre. 
Now, let me quickly talk as we could spend hours on our redevelopment and expansion at the end of the fourth quarter, but I'll give you some highlights. 
At the end of the fourth quarter, redevelopment expansion projects were ongoing at 29 properties across 3 of our platforms, with a total committed spent of $1.5 billion.
During the quarter, we opened 2 significant expansions and completed a number of others strategically developments, including the new faster wing at the llama, which includes the new Nordstrom's and more than 100 exceptional brands, the expansion of the sawgrass, where we added 20 small shops, very high and small shops and 2 restaurants and the redevelopment of fifth Woodfield Mall in Monroe Park.
We also started construction on several new projects during the quarter, including the shops at Riverside and Copley Place. Construction continues on other major redevelopment and expansion projects at some of our most productive properties including Roosevelt Field, Stanford, King of Prussia, Woodberry Commons, Gallery in Houston. Most of these projects will be completed in '16 and Houston Galleria will go into 17 as well.
Now, not to be ignored, we continued to be active on new development. We opened 2 new outlets during the quarter, in Tucson and Tampa both off a very strong sales start. Construction continues on 2 new domestic outlets in Columbus and Clarksburg. Both scheduled open later this year as well as the designer outlet in Vermont, France, which is scheduled to open in the spring of 2017.
We also started the construction in upscale outlet center in so Southwest so Seoul Korea, schedule to open in the spring of 2017. This will be our fourth year and we also recently announced a new partnership with Ivanhoe Cambridge to develop a premium outlet collection at Edmonton International Airport, which will be our 4th outlet in Canada. This is expected to open in the fall of 2017.
2 new full price developments are ongoing. As you know, what in Miami, opening this fall and Fort Worth at the shops at clear for scheduled to open in early 2017. Leasing demand at both are great. Brickle will be an Air Force will be open air and anchored by Neiman Marcus.
Portfolio changes we sold the shops at Sunset Place and we recently completed the sale of Columbia George outlet and we also recently acquired with our partner, McArthurGlen, the majority interest in a leading outlet center in our trip Germany, Northwest Germany. This successful center is well positioned within the market and had significant value added expansion opportunities.
Let me run through the balance sheet, 2 senior note offerings, and totaling $1.9 billion was down last day with an average weighted coupon of 2.34% term of 7.5. We redeemed 4 series Senior Notes, totaling 1.7, with an weighted average coupon of 6. We closed 23 new mortgages, with an average interest rate of 3.2% and 8.5 years. Our liquidity was $5.5 billion at the end of the quarter. Our fixed charge coverage is up to 4.5% -- I'm sorry 4.5x. And recently, we completed a very successful Senior Notes offering earlier this month raising $1.35 billion at an average interest rate and term of 2.9% and 8.2 years in a very volatile capital market scenario.
Dividends. We paid a record dividend in 2015 of $6.05 per share. This has achieved the compound annual growth rate of more than 18% over the last 5 years. We announced our dividend today to be paid this quarter of $1.60, which is an increase of 14% year-over-year. 
Okay. That's pretty busy. Now, let me talk about our guidance for '16. It's $10.70 to $10.80. This range represents 9% to 10% growth compared to FFO per share of $9.86 for 2015 and again, will be industry-leading.
Our range is based on the following assumptions, comp NOI for our portfolio of malls, outlets and Mills of at least 3.5% and total NOI growth of more than 6% for the portfolio. No additional planned acquisitions or retail disposition activity than what we recently completed.
Continued unfavorable impacts related to foreign currency devaluations which should affect us by approximately $0.05 compared to 2015. And importantly, we are not assuming any additional share count decrease, so on average diluted share count of 362 million. We are now looking forward to your questions. Operator are you with us?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum of UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum of UBS.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, you touched on the link between retailers having stores at your malls and Internet sales in that local market. One of the questions I get recently from investors is the concept of occupancy cost being measured as a percentage of sales just at that
componenttext: David, you touched on the link between retailers having stores at your malls and Internet sales in that local market. One of the questions I get recently from investors is the concept of occupancy cost being measured as a percentage of sales just at that mall store. When you are talking to retailers now about the rent they should be paying, how is the conversation going such that you can capture some of those Internet sales in the rents that you're charging them as the physical Mall? Because to me that seems like an important shift in the business going on.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, that separate media narrative to reality, but we are including anything, any sale that comes from their store, and it could be driven by the Internet is in our sales that come from that store. So we're getting the benefit of that.And so I s
componenttext:
Well, again, that separate media narrative to reality, but we are including anything, any sale that comes from their store, and it could be driven by the Internet is in our sales that come from that store. So we're getting the benefit of that.
And so I still think occupancy costs are still going to be very important to the overall negotiation of what the rent they're able to proceed. However, it is important to note that stores for these retailers are part of their your distribution network. And when they look at whether or not they're going to keep a store open, they're also going to evaluate, affect decrease in overall Internet sales might be in that market, and that is a benefit to us not that we have a lot of stores that are risk foreclosures other than through bankruptcies.
And at 12.3% given our productivity, and given we're rents are and what you've seen from history, I mean we still have a very good runaway to continue to increase our rents.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay, and then second question can you touch on your interest in Macy's real estate now that there clear that they want to do something there? And in particular, I guess in theory it would be with your Hudson's Bay Joint Venture but maybe just touch on your interest level there.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: There's been an important partner of ours. And obviously they have very good real estate's so I can say nothing really is happening that's material or meaningful other than our normal an ongoing business and that's been very productive. We have an excellent relationship with Macy's, both from a real estate and a corporate point of view. They've been very supportive in our efforts to enhance the quality of our real estate through our expansion and redevelopment activity, and if they've got ideas on how they want to look at the real estate, we are happy to do it. Either as part of the HBC JV or on our own but nothing really is happening other than day-to-day business content the only thing that I would add in that course of day-to-day business we acquire the Bloomingdale, Stanford demolished it, creating, small shop they build a new Bloomingdale's store we combined 3 Macy's stores to at Delaval and facilitate our expansion. So that day-to-day business those involved activities with respect to their existing stores.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look I think it's very interesting that the market needs to understand on these retailers, Macy's and the penny, down the list. I mean it's a vast, vast, vast majority of their stores have for wall pockets and Rick and I just do it to her in Texas this we
componenttext: Look I think it's very interesting that the market needs to understand on these retailers, Macy's and the penny, down the list. I mean it's a vast, vast, vast majority of their stores have for wall pockets and Rick and I just do it to her in Texas this week and I'll let you guys figure out for the retailers are, major note in Texas our and we hear that repeatedly. So Macy's I'm sure that vast, vast, vast, vast majority of their stores that they have, you now have a 4 wall pockets. I don't anticipate there are to be significant changes but we'll see. As it will give us opportunity. I think make a great points if we can pick up Bloomingdale's at Stanford in the middle of a mall and release it to high-end shops and they can build a new store that's a win-win for everybody involved so I think there will be a few of those as well.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael Bilerman for Misty question on balance sheet as you think about your very conservative balance sheet with exceptional cost of capital and access to capital and I'm curious as you think about maintaining really strong balance sheet. How much of it
componenttext: Michael Bilerman for Misty question on balance sheet as you think about your very conservative balance sheet with exceptional cost of capital and access to capital and I'm curious as you think about maintaining really strong balance sheet. How much of it is thinking about opportunities down the road and I don't know how quickly those opportunities will come in to view and how much is it your concern perhaps, about the macro environment. I recognize that use of capital can buybacks Stock, which you haven't really done for the backup of the year. You have a very large redevelopment pipeline, which is funded by free cash flow but your overall leverage metrics and access to capital have never been better in the company's history and I am just trying to think about what's driving that in your mind as you run the company?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's a great point and it's ignored a lot in terms of how people look at our company. but love the fact that our interest coverage is 4.5x given the size of our, I should say, fixed charge coverage not just interest coverage and I love the f
componenttext: Well, I think it's a great point and it's ignored a lot in terms of how people look at our company. but love the fact that our interest coverage is 4.5x given the size of our, I should say, fixed charge coverage not just interest coverage and I love the fact that we can fund our development and new development from our free cash flow and yet at the same time, have a compound annual growth rate dividend increase of 18%. I mean you can put those kind of metrics against anybody and you can't issue in a day, paper in under 3%, when the CMBS market is cracking and the life company market is cracking and the high-yield market is cracking and yet, we're able to go whether it's in the euro market or the U.S. fixed income market, but place that kind of paper in that kind of speed and it's undervalued by the equity markets. To me, that is sacrosanct. I have been really reluctant to enter the big deal business. I continue to be. We are so busy. I mean, as you know, I have a hard time speaking generally and when we write our script, I can get barely give the words out because I didn't take out cushion classes in high school. But the fact of the matter is we are extremely busy building and adding value to the portfolio using our external free cash flow. That remains the focus. I think will be very conservative on buying our stock back in today's market and my view on the big deal business really hasn't changed.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Christy here. Sales up 5% by 7%, which is encouraging. I'm wondering if you have a sense for what's driving that difference our people stay in the mall longer visiting peers stores or conversion entire, several retailers out there commenting that mal
componenttext: It's Christy here. Sales up 5% by 7%, which is encouraging. I'm wondering if you have a sense for what's driving that difference our people stay in the mall longer visiting peers stores or conversion entire, several retailers out there commenting that mall talk traffic is down and the impact that, that perception that share prices any information that we can get from your data?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's a very important point to make the following distinction. So remember, we get the overall traffic number and yet most of the folks that quote numbers are based on algorithms so it's not real necessarily data like we have. And number 2 is
componenttext:
Yes. I think it's a very important point to make the following distinction. So remember, we get the overall traffic number and yet most of the folks that quote numbers are based on algorithms so it's not real necessarily data like we have. And number 2 is it's derived from certain stores. So it doesn't necessarily equate to mall traffic, so It gives you store data but more not mall traffic data and that's the distinction. And really important make.
And I will tell you that trend though with mobile technology is in that the consumer today clearly is going to the physical environment, more educated, and doing less browsing and they're going to last store. We think that the store data that you get is in fact, may be it's a little bit not that far off but it doesn't represent mall traffic and I just think the consumer is going to do a few less stores because they are doing less of browsing because they are more informed to their visit. 
But overall, the mall traffic is what we say it is. Our comps sales are what they are. It's so operator driven. You could be in a category where 1 retailer is excelling and the other 1 is not. It's not tied. It's lifting all boots but it's really retail and operator driven. And the good news is overall, given the size of our portfolio, we can handle on this overall, we have a pretty good comps sales increases.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the bottom line is same number of people coming into the mall but sales are up 5 points of an percent. They're just spending more.
componenttext: So the bottom line is same number of people coming into the mall but sales are up 5 points of an percent. They're just spending more.

componenttext: It's Craig Schmidt. My question is really on the future role of anchors at retail malls. How is your view changing of the Anchors. I mean there's seem to be a lot of repurposing going on such as the JVs and. And I am also thinking about what you taught at a Florida more than what you're going to be doing to chop the Riverside. It seems like it's just taking so much different view of what the anchors?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's such I can let Rick weight in hero's such a real estate specific equation but in a lot of cases, the vendors that go into a department store in certain cases, would rather have mall stores. And when we feel and say that's the case what
componenttext: Well, I think it's such I can let Rick weight in hero's such a real estate specific equation but in a lot of cases, the vendors that go into a department store in certain cases, would rather have mall stores. And when we feel and say that's the case what we rather we just rather have the vendor as a retailer and we don't necessarily want to rely on the department store to bring those vendors. So again it's specific and it's all about creating the right environment and experience and in some cases, having department store as part of that is vital i.e. take Delaval with Norstrom. They built a fantastic store. It is so complementary to what we've done. We couldn't be prouder of that redevelopment and that Nordstrom store and the environment is helping us create. In other cases, the vendor, we have a sax store at Riverside. They don't do well in New Jersey at all. And we feel like those vendors that were in that store actually would have a better experience in our redone environment that they would in the Saks box. And Florida mall are a great example of just taking underperforming Saks that was not attracting the consumer. We went from, I think, a $10 million Saks to $50 million of revenue generated after repurposing thag box and that's what it's all about. Rick.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The only thing that I would add is that every mall has its own story. So for Franky, at Roosevelt Field, the addition of Neiman Marcus is going to be a fundamental expansion of the market area, and that's a traditional fashion anchor. At Florida mall
componenttext: Yes. The only thing that I would add is that every mall has its own story. So for Franky, at Roosevelt Field, the addition of Neiman Marcus is going to be a fundamental expansion of the market area, and that's a traditional fashion anchor. At Florida mall we added the experience that in that market is just doing great business and expand the trade area of that property. What we're all about is trying to put in the appropriate retailers to maximize the importance of our properties in the markets that they serve.

componenttext: On the call steadily increasing over the past few years. As you've done a good job of really being able to push the rents despite lower sales growth but I just wondering is this something we should be concerned about and? To what extent are retailers pushing back are the higher occupancy cost just a part of doing business in a strong mall now?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean at 12.32%, I would not worry at all. I think we have to put in perspective how much our growth is ahead of GDP growth. We are in a -- I mean if you look at our results this year and what we did above and beyond our expectations, take out the
componenttext: Well, I mean at 12.32%, I would not worry at all. I think we have to put in perspective how much our growth is ahead of GDP growth. We are in a -- I mean if you look at our results this year and what we did above and beyond our expectations, take out the extraordinary gain and loss that I mentioned, but if you just look at our numbers and the fact we overcame relatively softer retail environment. A lot of things going into that moved toward durable goods an increase in health care costs and taxes and general economic malaise. We overcame our foreign currency translation from outside of the U.S. here. And then, obviously, the strong dollar if you look at our outlet missing I mean traffic was up, outlet business and I mean traffic was up across the portfolio yet sales were down there because the international tourist spend less. It's pretty good execution with some of the headwinds that we've done. The 12.3% the way I look at it is an insurance policy against a slow growth U.S. economy that we continued to will outperform GDP growth. And if it were up 15%, 16%, maybe that's when we would raise the alarm. But at 12.3%, we've got great insurance to continue to grow the cash flow. And if you look at our comp NOI, which is our real number of at least 3.5%. What's the Goldman, Tell me what today's Goldman get their conservative economist to Goldman not the bullish ones get the 1 that you got in the closet was your GDP growth what are they saying to .2 percent, 1.5 I would say 1.5% and we're 200 basis points above that, and part of that is because we do have reasons that are under market and we will be able to continue to push that at the same time, our business is all about repeat business. We got to find a win-win with our retailers. We try to do the best we can meeting the expectations of our growth for us, for our investors at the same time, we went our retailers as strong as possible. That's a very -- it's challenging to find that equilibrium. We do a pretty good job of it and I'm confident we can continue to do it not completely sometimes we screw up on the various ends there but at the end of the day, we trying to find that equilibrium that will satisfy our retailer partner, satisfy our own internal expectations, satisfy our investors, that's why I've been able to -- we've been able to grow our earnings 14% per annum increase the dividend 18% per annum over a longer and of time, industry-leading and try to find that equilibrium. We have an insurance policy.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Got it. This is it sounds like we shouldn't be concerned yet.

componenttext: Okay, and then just regarding your current share price. The market appears to be supporting other mall REITs that might have some take a potential while perhaps, punishing you as a potential buyer so as stocks is down today can you comment on basically turning this argument over and by buying yourself and repurchasing shares. I know you mentioned before that you would be very conservative with doing that in the future.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well look I think what the Lehrmann said earlier we were out of the big deal business so people can speculate all they want. I do think the market should understand as our plan that we will be conservative on buybacks, as some of the higher -- I understan
componenttext: Well look I think what the Lehrmann said earlier we were out of the big deal business so people can speculate all they want. I do think the market should understand as our plan that we will be conservative on buybacks, as some of the higher -- I understand Tom, that some of the higher estimates out there on first call were due to the buyback numbers, so that's part of the issue there. We're going to be concerned there. I love having a great balance sheet. This is not a gain game year. This is long-term but I am out of the big deal business. Somebody wants to call me up and talk to me show me how to make money, I'm happy to have that conversation, but my opinion hasn't changed since really, last spring. So I don't really know what else I can tell you on that front. We won't be afraid to buy back stock, which is we're not planning right now. We have the authorization to do it. People are betting against that for whatever reason. That's the markets, but we have a growing dividend and growing earnings and as usually a bad thing to bet against.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just quickly, I go to the second question first and then I'll go to my first question second because you mentioned dividend. Last year you guys raised the dividend quarterly. Obviously, it was up almost 20% for the year. This year, should the expectati
componenttext: So just quickly, I go to the second question first and then I'll go to my first question second because you mentioned dividend. Last year you guys raised the dividend quarterly. Obviously, it was up almost 20% for the year. This year, should the expectation you didn't raise it for the fourth quarter so shall we think about this sort of normalized sort of annual increase? Or do you think you was a steady state of increase throughout the year and part of that is just read to read into cash flow use maybe with what's going on, you guys are trying to has been more cash or maybe it has just how you've been reading a lot last year and know you want to go back to an annual increase.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we've been chasing our taxable income as you know. There's a lot that goes into that equation. If we kept it at 160, that would be 6% growth year-over-year. I would think that, that would be at the bare minimum of what happens, but I would st
componenttext: Yes. I think we've been chasing our taxable income as you know. There's a lot that goes into that equation. If we kept it at 160, that would be 6% growth year-over-year. I would think that, that would be at the bare minimum of what happens, but I would start to like to get into a normalized, once a year, raise so we don't do it sequentially like we've been doing it quarter after quarter. I think that should be your expectation going forward. We'll probably assess that you're the end of this year now as we had in the past but that's subject to change obviously with the input of our taxable income calculation as well as obviously our board's input. At the very, very least 6% growth, over 6% growth, I would like for it to be annualized -- I'm sorry, once a year when we evaluate it, which would probably most likely be in the back half so we can position it for the preceding -- for the subsequent year. But as you know, with our NOI growth of at least over 6-plus percent, our taxable income is going to be increasing, so that will be driving our dividend increase up as well.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the second question is, I think it was in your response to Christy's question. If shoppers are getting more selective in visiting fewer stores. One, it sounds like a merchandising issue from retailers? And then, two, does that mean that we
componenttext: Okay. And then the second question is, I think it was in your response to Christy's question. If shoppers are getting more selective in visiting fewer stores. One, it sounds like a merchandising issue from retailers? And then, two, does that mean that we should expect higher retailer turnover like we should see more stores closing if they can't get their merchandising right? Or your view was the retailers that had trouble attracting shoppers last year are quickly addressing their merchandising issues?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I think the retailers clearly are in that boat. And they're not as -- we did experience in '15, a number of bankruptcies of kind of the really poor performing retailers. There was clearly a slowdown in retail sales in the back half of the year
componenttext: Well, look, I think the retailers clearly are in that boat. And they're not as -- we did experience in '15, a number of bankruptcies of kind of the really poor performing retailers. There was clearly a slowdown in retail sales in the back half of the year, and then when you couple that with the tourism issue, you couple that with the warmer weather, I mean, it was, so to speak, a perfect storm. It took a lot of retailers out. I mean we have seen this movie and I don't know it's Rocky 7. I'm ready for Creed. So we don't have to keep seeing this movie over again. I think our retailers are pretty sophisticated, adapting very aggressive and I think part of the responsibility of driving traffic to more stores, is the owners is on us, meaning we've got to create an environment, which does and is able to communicate to the consumer what's going on to the mall so that they can visit kind of more stores than they have that they leased it in '15 and take advantage of them when they're in our store. I think clearly as our retailers sync up their information, drive traffic to the stores, fulfill out of the stores, return out of the stores, I mean all that is going to be incremental as their systems get more sophisticated I think hopefully will extend stays and allow people to visit more stores. So it's all a work in progress. We've got to do some of that ourselves. And as you know, we're doing a lot of that. We're at the forefront of a lot of activity to try to figure out how the best way to communicate to the consumer so they go see 8 or 10 stores as opposed to 4 or 5 or 6.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay and then just I know how much you love your crooked stick suggestion box, but as you guys view a lot of the development and redevelopment it would just be helpful from our end to have a table on the sub that just sort of quantify the amount and quarter that developments and redevelopments will come online just for modeling perspective.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I'm happy to do that. Now, I will say this. I know there was a comment or 2 that's said about our return is going down. Absolutely not. Our mix changes every quarter, which we probably time to be do a better job of pointing that out. And I assure
componenttext: I think I'm happy to do that. Now, I will say this. I know there was a comment or 2 that's said about our return is going down. Absolutely not. Our mix changes every quarter, which we probably time to be do a better job of pointing that out. And I assure you that we if we are going to deliver, I mean we do have to have a materiality threshold to the size of our company, but I assure you in the market that we have a major development or a major redevelopment where we're working to lay an egg, will let you know. That's not what happened in today's supplements. We have some things come off and we had some things come on, just like we do every quarter. And Tom is happy to walk you through what went in and what went out. But I assure the market we're going to lay an egg for anything that's new, whether it's new or redevelopment, we'll let you know. With some materiality threshold obviously. But that's not the case with the changes in our development pipeline and redevelopment pipeline.

componenttext: Remember our comp you got to be in place in 24 months, so that's not the case. That's number 1. And number 2, I mean we did have our -- we did have slippage in our tourist-oriented centers, not just the outlets but in the number of malls that were, had to deal with. And again, it was not a traffic issue a it's not anything other than, and I know you seen it from the retailers, but the tourism that is important to the economic growth of United States of America may have come, but they spend less. And we have unbelievable great properties in the long run, our fantastic and it would sales that. I mean we have small shops and medium-sized shops between $30 million to $40 million of volumes under these places but the tourism sector that and as you know, we got a lot going on in some of our major properties moving tenants in and out so you're putting it all together total sales were relatively flat's. We don't view that as a big deal.

componenttext: 70%. Okay and that I guess as it comes to in terms of bankruptcies this year I realize you guys got hit pretty hard last year working through. What is your expectation for bankruptcy this year? And how is that impact is sort of your 3.5% NOI number that you're giving us?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well it is. I mean we still have lease up from last year. And we have budget in some of the weaker tenants whether they go bankrupt or we do. We renegotiate short-term deals while we face some smaller tenants. I mean that's all factored in there. We've be
componenttext: Well it is. I mean we still have lease up from last year. And we have budget in some of the weaker tenants whether they go bankrupt or we do. We renegotiate short-term deals while we face some smaller tenants. I mean that's all factored in there. We've been conservative on overage rents. I mean they're not a perfect science model, nor is the U.S. economy so we do the best that we can budgeting the best that we can, being as conservative as we can. We clearly thought in '15, we would hit 4%, we didn't because of the overage rent thing that we did mention, that was, as you know, overage rent, we hit breakpoints so if you're over the breakpoints there's a lot of volatility the fourth quarter is important in total sales. I mean that's hard necessarily to model. We took a very conservative approach in how we look at the books at year end and we're taking a reasonably conservative approach. We still have work to do but conservative sales, conservative lease up, conservative restructurings and search in tenants, whether in and out of bankruptcy, is all factored into that number. But importantly, Steve, and this is a true distinction. I mean our number is -- our 3.5 is different than most people, okay. So you have to put that into perspective.

Again, it's not like we're delivering these things at 60% occupied, 50%. 90.7% at the end of year 1, it's pretty good. So I think that's pretty good execution.

componenttext: Well, I mean we don't want excuses but yes, most we ripped out King of Prussia and we those we're in take out of our sales numbers and those things you move tenants around. So that's clearly affecting us but you know at the end of the day, we're just not going to use that as a basis to say here's a little bit of a slippage but yes, it clearly affected '15 both from a NOI point of view and a sales point of view because there's a lot of these were moving traffic around, were closing the entrances and there's absolutely dislocation going on.

componenttextpreview: Well, I think our portfolio is -- our results and our averages are indicative of kind of what results were. I don't think there's any unusual trend. I think the market sometimes maybe overreacts. The only game in town Mall. We think that business is a goo
componenttext: Well, I think our portfolio is -- our results and our averages are indicative of kind of what results were. I don't think there's any unusual trend. I think the market sometimes maybe overreacts. The only game in town Mall. We think that business is a good and very viable. In that only game in town market has too much retail it's going to be hurt but that could be in the market too. I don't think we don't had any unpleasant surprises the not exciting markets that we still own. The only thing that was a little out of the ordinary from our results this year was the tourist spend that we mentioned. And obviously that happened at some of our most unique landmark properties. I mean they can't hide from that fact, not a long-term issue. I hope but the tourists reigned it a little bit. They reigned in New York City, Madison Avenue, Fifth Avenue, down in Miami, north and south of the Canadian dollar, the Mexican peso. We have Mexican nationals that shop at some of our premiere properties and you get the Canadian snowbirds. I mean that happens. That's the only trend that I would say it's a little bit different than what we've experienced, not only game in town, which is we are in some of those markets but they continued to perform very well.

componenttextpreview: No. The reality is I wish they were at market because then the volatility -- so you know, when we roll over a lease, we try to get effective rent, which is base rent plus overage rent and the reason we have a little more volatility is because the lease ha
componenttext: No. The reality is I wish they were at market because then the volatility -- so you know, when we roll over a lease, we try to get effective rent, which is base rent plus overage rent and the reason we have a little more volatility is because the lease hasn't expired. So the good news skis as these leases expire. We're going to be able to get them at market rent. I mean that's why we had a little exposure in the fourth quarter because we're not at market rent. We're not at market rent. So even with today's decrease in tourism spend, the important point though also is that the traffic was up, and so that's an important point. I mean the traffic was up. It was really just the spend was down. I think that's just going to be an adjustment until we get where the currencies are little more stable and anniversary themselves. But it's our intention to make that volatility go away and that's marking the leasing the market.

componenttext: This is Rick. In fact, we were doing very well with that releasing. What we are going to do is we're not going to put our space on sales. We're holding our margins. componenttextpreview: When we do our leasing, every space and every tenant has their own situation and we are strategic about our terms. If we feel that it's a tenant that is underperforming in the mall, maybe we'll do a shorter term. If it's a tenant that were highly desires
componenttext: When we do our leasing, every space and every tenant has their own situation and we are strategic about our terms. If we feel that it's a tenant that is underperforming in the mall, maybe we'll do a shorter term. If it's a tenant that were highly desires of having in the mall, we want them to remodel, we make it longer term. So there's no overarching strategy on term. It's really a lease specific strategic decision.

componenttext: No. This at the end of the day, we made our FFO this year was $3.6 billion, right? Which happened to be more than certain technology companies. I won't name names, okay? And I know everybody wants all these metrics but you got to look at what it's all about, which is growing earnings, growing dividends, investing for the future. And I do think there is this move on metrics that I just want to put in an overall perspective that it's not how we -- we don't stress over metrics the way others might. We're just focus on increasing our cash flow, investing for the future, making our properties in the best they can be in a particular market, for the benefit of the shareholders, communities, retailers and we will just tell you that we, as we model all this, we're expecting an increase in occupancy. It takes a lot of work. How many leases do we sign these-year, my friends?

I mean we started out with I think if I can remember the math, $200 million of earnings. We're at $3.6 billion, okay? That's not too shabby. As I said in my annual report quoting Adam Sandler nobody liked but I find it funny. But the point is, I don't know. without a run good run rate for the next 3 years, Floris.

componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter Simon Property Group 2015 Earnings Call. My name is Lauren, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the conference over to Tom Ward, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lauren. Good morning, everyone. Presenting on today's call is David Simon, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Also on the call are Rick Sokolov, President and Chief Operating Officer; Andy Juster, Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Broadwate
componenttext:
Thank you, Lauren. Good morning, everyone. Presenting on today's call is David Simon, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Also on the call are Rick Sokolov, President and Chief Operating Officer; Andy Juster, Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Broadwater, our Chief Accounting Officer.
Before we begin, a quick reminder that statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, and actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. We refer you to today's press release and our SEC filings for a detailed discussion of forward-looking statements.
Please note that this call includes information that may be accurate only as of today's date. Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included within the press release and the supplemental information in today's Form 8-K filing. Both the press release and the supplemental information are available on our IR website at investors.simon.com.
For our prepared remarks, I'm pleased to introduce David Simon.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. We had strong results to wrap up a great year. We opened, started and completed several new development and redevelopment projects. We successfully executed several capital market transaction, extending our average term and reducing our weig
componenttext:
Good morning. We had strong results to wrap up a great year. We opened, started and completed several new development and redevelopment projects. We successfully executed several capital market transaction, extending our average term and reducing our weighted interest costs. We continued to achieve strong operating and financial results.
Our full year 2015 FFO per share was $9.86, which beat our initial guidance range of $9.60 to $9.70 a share, even with a net $0.11 loss reported during the year, which was derived from $0.33 loss on extinguishment of debt, partially offset by $0.22 gain upon the sale of marketable securities that occurred in the year as well as a $0.12 of negative impact from foreign currency devaluations.
On a comparable basis, excluding the impact of -- from WPG spinoff in the prior year and the net loss mentioned above, full year FFO increased 11.4% to $9.97 per diluted share. We posted record FFO results once again and have achieved a compound annual FFO growth rate of more than 14% over the last 5 years.
For the fourth quarter, FFO of $2.40 per share included a $0.33 loss on extinguishment of debt and exceeded the consensus estimate by $0.02. On a comparable basis, excluding the loss on the extinguishment of debt in the quarter, FFO per diluted share increased 10.5% year-over-year.
Now let me turn to operating metrics and cash flow. Our Malls and Premium Outlets occupancy ended the year at 96.1%. This was 100% -- 100 basis points lower than year-end 2014 due to the timing of a lease-up of more than 2 million square feet of new space we brought online this year from expansions and new developments as well as replacing the 1.3 million square feet of space lost due to tenant bankruptcies during the year.
Importantly, we are more than 90% leased on the new space we brought online this year. The timing of the lease-up on the remaining space to be leased impacted our year-end occupancy by approximately 50 basis points.
By the end of the year, we replaced more than 70% of the space lost to tenant bankruptcies, and the remaining space to be leased impacted occupancy by 50 basis points as well. Put the 2 together and that's a 100 basis point differential. 
Leasing activity remains healthy as evidenced by the Mall and Premium Outlets' recorded leasing spreads of $10.63 per foot, an increase of 18%, and the base minimum rent was $48.96, which was up more than 4% compared to last year, reflecting strong retailer demand for our locations.
As I mentioned, retailer demand for space remained strong. Retailers who want to grow their business are adding brand extensions and creating new brands and pureplay e-tailers who want physical locations to increase their revenues. E-tailers who opened bricks and mortar stores experienced increased consumer awareness and subsequently greater organic site traffic and lower customer acquisition costs. We have repeatedly heard from retailers that online sales is directly influenced by the presence of a physical store in that market. When a retailer opens a physical store in a market, they see their online sales increase and, likewise, if they close the store, they see their online sales in that market decline. Successful omni-channel retailers are increasing their buy online and pick up in store. This functionality not only increases convenience for shoppers but also facilitates incremental purchases and up-sell opportunities when the shopper enters our retail environment.
For 2015, sales per square foot for our Mall and Premium Outlets were $620 a foot compared to $619. Comparable sales per square foot for the Malls increased 5.7%. We were up a greater amount at The Mills, and we were down slightly at our tourist-oriented Premium Outlets and up slightly at our non-tourist outlet centers. We have great centers in key tourist locations that generate incredible sales volume and at the envy of the industry. The strong dollar, however, impacted tenant sales at these unique centers, which negatively affected our overage rent for the quarter.
And I know you've all heard about mall traffic decreases. Now let me give you some facts based on our internal data across the largest retail portfolio in the U.S. and not just estimates derived from arbitrary algorithms. Traffic at our Malls was flat for the year, including the holiday season. Traffic at our Premium Outlets increased 1.5% for the year and more than 2% for the holidays. And traffic at The Mills increased slightly for the year as well.
Comp NOI increased 3.7% for the full year 2015 and increased 3.4% for the fourth quarter of 2015. For the fourth quarter, overage rent declined $13 million year-over-year due to the lower sales volumes that I mentioned already at our tourist-oriented centers. The lower overage rent impacted our comp NOI for the quarter of approximately 100 basis points. I will strongly remind you, we do not include lease settlement income, new acquisitions or the impact of recently redeveloped or expanded centers in our comp NOIs -- in our comp NOI number.
Total NOI from our consolidated and unconsolidated properties increased more than 7% to $5.8 billion in 2015. That was on top of 6.7% growth in 2014, and this includes any NOI contribution for -- from Kl√©pierre. 
Now let me quickly talk because we could spend hours on our redevelopment and expansion. At the end of the fourth quarter -- but I'll give you some highlights. At the end of the fourth quarter, redevelopment expansion projects were ongoing at 29 properties across all 3 of our platforms, with a total committed spend of $1.5 billion.
During the quarter, we opened 2 significant expansions and completed a number of other strategic redevelopments, including the new Fashion Wing at Del Amo, which includes a new Nordstrom and more than 100 exceptional brands; the expansion of The Colonnade and Sawgrass, where we added 20 small shops, very high-end small shops, and 2 restaurants and the redevelopment at Phipps, Woodfield Mall and Menlo Park.
We also started construction on several new projects during the quarter, including the shops at Riverside and Copley Place. Construction continues on other major redevelopment and expansion projects at some of our most productive properties, including Roosevelt Field, Stanford, King of Prussia, Woodbury Commons, The Galleria in Houston. Most of these projects will be completed in '16, and Houston Galleria will go into '17 as well.
Now on the -- not to be ignored, we continue to be active on new development. We opened 2 new outlets during the quarter in Tucson and Tampa, both off a very strong sales start. Construction continues on 2 new domestic outlets in Columbus and Clarksburg. Both scheduled to open later this year as well as a designer outlet in Provence, France, which is scheduled to open in the spring of 2017.
We also started construction in upscale outlet center in Seoul -- Southwest Seoul, Korea, scheduled to open in the spring of 2017. This will be our fourth year. And we also recently announced a new partnership with Ivanhoe Cambridge to develop a premium outlet collection at Edmonton International Airport, which will be our 4th outlet in Canada. This is expected to open in the fall of 2017.
2 new full price developments are ongoing. As you know, one in Miami at Brickell Centre opening this fall and Fort Worth at The Shops at Clearfork scheduled to open in early 2017. Leasing demand at both are great. Brickell will be anchored by Saks. Clearfork will be open-air and anchored by Neiman Marcus.
Portfolio changes. We sold The Shops at Sunset Place, and we recently completed the sale of Columbia Gorge Outlet. And we also recently acquired with our partner, McArthurGlen, the majority interest in a leading outlet center in Ochtrup, Germany, Northwest Germany. This successful center is well-positioned within the market and has significant value-added expansion opportunities.
Let me run through the balance sheet. 2 senior note offerings and -- totaling $1.9 billion was down last day, with an average weighted coupon of 2.34%, term of 7.5. We redeemed 4 series of senior notes totaling 1.7, with an weighted average coupon of 6%. We closed 23 new mortgages, with an average interest rate of 3.2% and 8.5 years. Our liquidity was $5.5 billion at the end of the quarter. Our fixed charge coverage is up to 4.5% -- or, I'm sorry, 4.5x. And recently, we completed a very successful senior notes offering earlier this month, raising $1.35 billion at an average interest rate and term of 2.9% at 8.2 years in a very volatile capital market scenario.
Dividends. We paid a record dividend in 2015 of $6.05 per share. This has achieved the compound annual growth rate of more than 18% over the last 5 years. We announced our dividend today to be paid this quarter of $1.60, which is an increase of 14% year-over-year. 
Okay. That's pretty busy. Now let me talk about our guidance for '16. It's $10.70 to $10.80. This range represents 9% to 10% growth compared to the FFO per share of $9.86 for 2015 and, again, will be industry-leading.
Our range is based on the following assumptions: comp NOI for our portfolio of Malls, Outlets and Mills of at least 3.5% and total NOI growth of more than 6% for the portfolio. No additional planned acquisition or retail disposition activity than what we recently completed. Continued unfavorable impacts related to foreign currency devaluations, which should affect us by approximately $0.05 compared to 2015. And importantly, we are not assuming any additional share count decrease, so on average, diluted share count of 362 million. 
We are now looking forward to your questions. Operator, are you with us?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum, UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Ross Nussbaum, UBS.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, you touched on the link between retailers having stores at your malls and Internet sales in that local market. One of the questions I get recently from investors is the concept of occupancy costs being measured as a percentage of sales just at that
componenttext: David, you touched on the link between retailers having stores at your malls and Internet sales in that local market. One of the questions I get recently from investors is the concept of occupancy costs being measured as a percentage of sales just at that mall store. When you're talking to retailers now about the rent they should be paying, how is the conversation going such that you can capture some of those Internet sales in the rents that you're charging them at the physical mall? Because to me, that seems like an important shift in the business going on.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't -- again, I -- let's separate media narrative to reality. But we're -- we are including anything -- any sale that comes from their store, and it could be driven by the Internet, is in our sales that come from that store. So we're getting the
componenttext: Well, I don't -- again, I -- let's separate media narrative to reality. But we're -- we are including anything -- any sale that comes from their store, and it could be driven by the Internet, is in our sales that come from that store. So we're getting the benefit of that. And so I still think occupancy costs are still going to be very important to the overall negotiation of what the rent they're able to proceed. However, it is important to note that stores for these retailers are part of their your distribution network. And when they look at whether or not they're going to keep a store open, they're also going to affect -- evaluate what their decrease in overall Internet sales might be in that market. And that is a benefit to us, not that we have a lot of stores that are at risk for closures, other than through bankruptcies. So -- and at 12.3%, given our productivity and given where our rents are and what you've seen from the history, I mean, we've got -- we still have a very good runway to continue to increase our rents.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second question. Can you touch on your interest in Macy's real estate now that they're clear that they may want to do something there? And in particular, I guess, in theory, it would be with your Hudson's Bay joint venture, but maybe just t
componenttext: Okay. And then second question. Can you touch on your interest in Macy's real estate now that they're clear that they may want to do something there? And in particular, I guess, in theory, it would be with your Hudson's Bay joint venture, but maybe just touch on your interest level there.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, they've been an important partner of ours, and obviously, they have very good real estates. So I can say nothing really is happening that's material or meaningful, other than our normal ongoing business, and that's been very productive. And we
componenttext: Well, look, they've been an important partner of ours, and obviously, they have very good real estates. So I can say nothing really is happening that's material or meaningful, other than our normal ongoing business, and that's been very productive. And we have an excellent relationship with Macy's, both from a real estate and a corporate point of view. They've been very supportive in our efforts to enhance the quality of our real estate through our expansion and redevelopment activity. And if they've got ideas on how they want to look at the real estate, we're happy to do it, either as part of the HBC JV or on our own. But nothing really is happening other than day-to-day business.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only thing that I would add in the course of that day-to-day business, we acquired a Bloomingdale's store at Stanford, demolished it, creating small shop. They built a new Bloomingdale's store. We combined 3 Macy's stores into 2 at Del Amo to faci
componenttext: And the only thing that I would add in the course of that day-to-day business, we acquired a Bloomingdale's store at Stanford, demolished it, creating small shop. They built a new Bloomingdale's store. We combined 3 Macy's stores into 2 at Del Amo to facilitate our expansion. So that day-to-day business does involve activities with respect to their existing stores.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, look, I think it's very interesting that the market needs to understand on these retailers, Macy's and the Penney and down the list. I mean, the vast, vast, vast majority of their stores have four-wall profits. And Rick and I just did a tour in Texas
componenttext: And, look, I think it's very interesting that the market needs to understand on these retailers, Macy's and the Penney and down the list. I mean, the vast, vast, vast majority of their stores have four-wall profits. And Rick and I just did a tour in Texas this week, and I'll let you guys figure out who the retailers are of major note in Texas are. And we hear that repeatedly. So Macy's, I'm sure the vast, vast, vast majority of those stores that they have are -- have four-wall profits. So I don't anticipate there to be significant changes, but we'll see. And I think it will give us the opportunity. I think Rick made a great point in that we can pick off a Bloomingdale's at Stanford in the middle of a mall and release it to high-end shops and they can build a new store. That's a win-win for everybody involved. So I think there'll be a few of those as well.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Christy McElroy, Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Christy McElroy, Citi.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, it's Michael Bilerman with Christy. Just a question about the balance sheet and as you think about your very conservative balance sheet with exceptional cost of capital and access to capital. And I'm curious, as you think about maintaining that rea
componenttext: David, it's Michael Bilerman with Christy. Just a question about the balance sheet and as you think about your very conservative balance sheet with exceptional cost of capital and access to capital. And I'm curious, as you think about maintaining that really strong balance sheet, how much of it is thinking about opportunities down the road? And I don't know how quickly those opportunities will come in to view. And how much is it your concern, perhaps, about the macro environment? And I recognize that use of capital you can buy back stock, which you haven't really done in the back half of the year. And you have a very large development -- redevelopment pipeline, which is funded by free cash flow. But your overall leverage metrics and access to capital are -- never been better in the company's history. And I'm just trying to think about what's driving that in your mind as you run the company.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's a great point and it's ignored a lot in terms of how people look at our company. But I love the fact that our interest coverage is 4.5x given the size of our -- I should say fixed charge coverage, not just interest coverage. And I love
componenttext: Well, I think it's a great point and it's ignored a lot in terms of how people look at our company. But I love the fact that our interest coverage is 4.5x given the size of our -- I should say fixed charge coverage, not just interest coverage. And I love the fact that we can fund our development and new development from our free cash flow and yet, at the same time, have a compound annual growth rate dividend increase of 18%. I mean, you can't put those kind of metrics against anybody, and you can't issue in a day paper at under 3% when the CMBS market is cracking and the life company market is cracking and the high-yield market is cracking. And yet we're able to go whether it's in the euro market or the U.S. fixed income market, but place that kind of paper in that kind of speed. And it's undervalued by the equity markets. To me, that is sacrosanct. And I have been very reluctant to enter the big deal business. I continue to be. And we're -- we are so busy. I mean, I -- as you know, I have a hard time speaking generally, and I -- when they get -- when we write our script, I can get barely get the words out because I didn't take elocution classes in high school. But the fact of the matter is, we are extremely busy building and adding value to the portfolio using our external free cash flow. That remains the focus. I think we'll be very conservative on buying our stock back in today's market, and my view on the big deal business really hasn't changed.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, it's Christy here. Just following up on some of the stats that you mentioned earlier, with traffic in the Malls flat but sales up 5.7%, which is encouraging. I'm wondering if you have a sense for what's driving that differential. Are people staying
componenttext:
David, it's Christy here. Just following up on some of the stats that you mentioned earlier, with traffic in the Malls flat but sales up 5.7%, which is encouraging. I'm wondering if you have a sense for what's driving that differential. Are people staying in a mall longer, visiting fewer stores? Are conversions higher? Just with several retailers out there commenting that mall traffic is down and the impact that, that perception is 
[Technical Difficulty] 
share prices. Just any information that we can get from your data would be helpful.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's a very important point to make the following distinction. So remember, we get the overall traffic number, and yet most of the folks that quote numbers are based on algorithms. So it's not real necessarily data like we have. And number tw
componenttext: Yes. I think it's a very important point to make the following distinction. So remember, we get the overall traffic number, and yet most of the folks that quote numbers are based on algorithms. So it's not real necessarily data like we have. And number two is it is derived from certain stores. So it doesn't necessarily equate to mall traffic. And it gives you store data but not mall traffic data. And that's the distinction that I -- really important make. And I will tell you, the trend though with mobile technology is that the consumer today clearly is going to the physical environment more educated, they're doing less browsing and they're going to less stores. So we think that the store data that you get is, in fact, maybe it's a little bit not that far off, but it doesn't represent mall traffic. And I just think the consumer is going to a few less stores because they are doing less browsing because they're more informed prior to their visit. But overall, the mall traffic is what we say it is. Our comp sales are what they are. And it's so operator-driven. You could be in a category where 1 retailer is excelling and another one's not. And it is -- it's not tide that's lifting all boats, but it's really retail and operator-driven. And the good news is, overall, and given the size of our portfolio, we have a pretty good handle on this, overall, we're having pretty good comp sales increases.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the bottom line is if the same number of people are coming to the mall but sales are up 5.7%  they're just spending more while they're there?
componenttext: So the bottom line is if the same number of people are coming to the mall but sales are up 5.7%  they're just spending more while they're there?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's the bottom line. And they may be going to a few less stores. I think -- yes, you're probably right. I probably could have shortened the explanation, but that's the bottom line.
componenttext: That's the bottom line. And they may be going to a few less stores. I think -- yes, you're probably right. I probably could have shortened the explanation, but that's the bottom line.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Corey (sic) [Craig] Schmidt, Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Corey (sic) [Craig] Schmidt, Bank of America.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Craig Schmidt. My question is really on the future role of anchors at regional malls. How is your view changing of the anchors? I mean, there seems to be a lot of repurposing going on, such as the JVs and Seritage. And I'm also thinking about what yo
componenttext: It's Craig Schmidt. My question is really on the future role of anchors at regional malls. How is your view changing of the anchors? I mean, there seems to be a lot of repurposing going on, such as the JVs and Seritage. And I'm also thinking about what you've done at Florida Mall and what you're going to be doing at Shops at Riverside. It seems like you're just taking a somewhat different view of what the anchor's role is.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I think it's such a -- and I'll let Rick weigh in here. I mean, it's such a real estate-specific equation. But in a lot of cases, the vendors that go into a department store, in certain cases, would rather have mall stores. And when we feel as
componenttext: Well, look, I think it's such a -- and I'll let Rick weigh in here. I mean, it's such a real estate-specific equation. But in a lot of cases, the vendors that go into a department store, in certain cases, would rather have mall stores. And when we feel as if that's the case, well, we'd rather just have the mall -- we'd just rather have the vendor as a retailer, and we don't necessarily want to rely on the department store to bring those vendors. So again, it's specific and it's all about creating the right environment and experience. And, in some cases, having department store as part of that is vital, i.e., take Del Amo with Nordstrom. They built a fantastic store. It is so complementary to what we've done. We couldn't be prouder of that redevelopment and that Nordstrom store and the environment its helping us create. In other cases, the vendor, we have a Saks store at Riverside. They don't do well in New Jersey all -- at all. And we feel like those vendors that were in that store actually would have a better experience in our redone environment than they would in the Saks box. So it's -- and Florida Mall is a great example of just taking underperforming Saks that was not attracting the consumer. We went from, I think, at $10 million Saks to $50 million of revenue generated after repurposing that box. And that's what it's all about. Rick?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, the only thing I would add is that every mall has its own story. So, frankly, at Roosevelt Field, the addition of Neiman Marcus is going to be a fundamental expansion of the market area. That's a traditional fashion anchor. At Florida Mall, we
componenttext: Yes. Well, the only thing I would add is that every mall has its own story. So, frankly, at Roosevelt Field, the addition of Neiman Marcus is going to be a fundamental expansion of the market area. That's a traditional fashion anchor. At Florida Mall, we added the Crayola Experience that, in that market, is just doing great business and expands the trade area of that property. What we're all about is trying to put in the appropriate retailers to maximize the importance of our properties in the markets that they serve.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And how is some of the progress on your JVs with Seritage?

componenttext: Pretty good. I just had breakfast with Ben. I think, hopefully, we'll get 4 or 5 starred this year, Rick, right?

componenttext: Yes.
