headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I appreciate hearing some additional comments. It helped answer my first question as to how things have changed in the last year. I guess, thinking about it, David, would you consider disclosing the latest occupancy cost of sales for the outlets, just
componenttext: And I appreciate hearing some additional comments. It helped answer my first question as to how things have changed in the last year. I guess, thinking about it, David, would you consider disclosing the latest occupancy cost of sales for the outlets, just to demonstrate the ability to continue to push rents further? Or at this point, are you just combining it with the malls?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've always -- we've combined them for the last several years. I mean, any -- look, I think all of these metrics manifest itself in their cash flow and comp NOI. And we are not as obsessed with metrics as maybe the analytic community. That could be
componenttext: Well, we've always -- we've combined them for the last several years. I mean, any -- look, I think all of these metrics manifest itself in their cash flow and comp NOI. And we are not as obsessed with metrics as maybe the analytic community. That could be good or that could be bad, but that's just the way we look at things. We also take a longer-term view of the real estate than we do on a quarter-by-quarter and even a year-by-year view. So I don't think that, that is going to do you any good, frankly. It's not something we're like obsessed with, "Oh, what's the occupancy cost going to be in this particular deal, with this particular tenant?" It's not how we run the business. We're looking at retail mix with a primary purpose that the retailer does well and the consumer likes it. And then if that works together, then it -- then hopefully, it will create the environment that we're trying to do, which, by the way, you're not -- we're decent at, good at, we're not great at, we can always do better. So another metric is just -- we just -- it's just not where we want you to think about us. I want you to think about our cash flow growth, our investment in our assets over the long term and so on. But all I can tell you is the outlet business comp NOI growth is doing very well, and we don't see a change in that even with the tourism slowdown that we're currently experiencing. Now we're -- we are -- our portfolio NOI grew 7.8%, with tough tourism spend and a slow growth economy. That's pretty good work. I can't guarantee we're going to do it every quarter, but I think that's pretty good work. That's what I'd like you to focus on.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Sounds good. And then my last question is just on retailer CapEx tenant allowance. Any change there as we think about how you're signing deals or some of your competitors? Is that increasing for some, decreasing? Is it similar to what we've seen in

componenttext: If you look in the Q, our allowance has been flat year-over-year. And frankly, all that allowance is just for new tenants. We have minimal now allowance for our renewal.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Christy McElroy from Citibank.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Michael Bilerman. David, I'm curious. As you think about all the investments you're making in the mall of the future, how do you think effectively the return on that capital will come? Do you think it's going to come direct from the consumer to
componenttext: Yes, it's Michael Bilerman. David, I'm curious. As you think about all the investments you're making in the mall of the future, how do you think effectively the return on that capital will come? Do you think it's going to come direct from the consumer to you? Or do you think it's going to come in the form of better sales, better productivity, better margins of your tenants and, therefore, higher rents that are able to be paid to you? And maybe just talk about where we are in sort of your view about how close we are to this mall of the future that you envision?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're still in the very early stages. I mean, I wish we were more along that curve, but it's not easy. I would say to you first -- but there's lots of things we're experimenting with. And I continue to think that as we do those investments,
componenttext: Well, I think we're still in the very early stages. I mean, I wish we were more along that curve, but it's not easy. I would say to you first -- but there's lots of things we're experimenting with. And I continue to think that as we do those investments, that the consumer will appreciate them and will lead to more traffic and more visits and more browsing, which is very important. I would say to you, the -- I don't necessarily see -- I see it more as creating a better environment, which will lead to all the benefits of that as opposed to the consumer is going to pay us for. The consumer, frankly, as we all know, is getting a lot of stuff subsidized right now because of what's going on in the broader world, delivery, returns, just to name a couple. So I see it more as creating an environment that's going to drive traffic and lead to more demand from retailers wanting to be in those places where traffic is. And more demand, I think, relates to -- for us, hopefully, we'll be able to generate more cash because supply and demand is important in every industry and, obviously, very important in the real estate industry. So I think it's more that. But I wouldn't rule out the consumer. But I think it's more creating the appropriate environment. If -- to give you a simple answer today, I'd say we're early days in that, but we're hopeful to continue to improve the environment.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm curious how much buying you have from the retailers to sort of experimenting and bringing more experience-based things to their stores and, clearly, doing all the stuff in terms of parking and direct on the consumer side to get them to come to the mal
componenttext: I'm curious how much buying you have from the retailers to sort of experimenting and bringing more experience-based things to their stores and, clearly, doing all the stuff in terms of parking and direct on the consumer side to get them to come to the mall. But is there some retailers that are being better partners in terms of just trying to drive that increased traffic?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think they're all very focused on it. I think the relationship on that front is excellent. We're getting a lot of cooperation buy-in. It obviously depends on the sophistication of the retailer. And frankly, they're very busy, too. But the good news
componenttext: Yes. I think they're all very focused on it. I think the relationship on that front is excellent. We're getting a lot of cooperation buy-in. It obviously depends on the sophistication of the retailer. And frankly, they're very busy, too. But the good news is, when we describe to them what we're trying to achieve and how they can play a role in, they're all very receptive. But they all -- they're also all very busy as well. So it's -- for us, it's prioritizing the biggest bang for their buck, making it easy as possible in terms of plug-and-play almost to use a technology terminology. We can deliver that to the retailer. That's a lot easier. I mean, it gets a little gruesome with the details, which I'll spare you and me and everybody else on the call to go into that level. But I think they're being excellent, they're being very cooperative. And we all want to drive traffic to the physical world, and we all see the benefit of that. And we'll continue to experiment and plug along here.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Floris van Dijkum from Boenning.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, could you -- your gross international NOI exposure is 8% today. What is your net exposure? And would you consider expanding your international NOI based on low interest rates on offer in both Europe and in Japan? And in particular, when you look at
componenttext: Dave, could you -- your gross international NOI exposure is 8% today. What is your net exposure? And would you consider expanding your international NOI based on low interest rates on offer in both Europe and in Japan? And in particular, when you look at your European outlets platform, do you think you can expand that by another 3 million square feet over the next 5 years?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I think we do want to expand our Asian premium outlet portfolio, but we only want to do it when there's supply and demand. We don't want to do it because of low interest rates. And I -- we feel strongly about our McArthurGlen relationship as w
componenttext: Well, look, I think we do want to expand our Asian premium outlet portfolio, but we only want to do it when there's supply and demand. We don't want to do it because of low interest rates. And I -- we feel strongly about our McArthurGlen relationship as well. And the good news is having been back and forth to see the MGE folks twice in the last, I don't know, 4 or 5 weeks. They have a very good pipe. So the answer there is, yes, we want to build out their pipe in Continental Europe and the U.K. And we certainly want to -- we certainly got a handful of opportunities in Asia as well. And listen, the low interest rates certainly make it easier in a sense, but it's always supply and demand. Can we lease the building? That's -- can we lease the building and at what rent? On your net question, are you asking from a hedging point of view? I wasn't really sure what you meant by the gross versus the net. So maybe if I could ask you again that.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes. It's both on an asset. And obviously, you're partly hedged through local debt but also on an FFO contribution in terms of your interest expense in local currencies. What is your -- what's your interest -- sorry, what's your currency risk in tha
componenttext: Sure. Yes. It's both on an asset. And obviously, you're partly hedged through local debt but also on an FFO contribution in terms of your interest expense in local currencies. What is your -- what's your interest -- sorry, what's your currency risk in that income on both the asset as well as the income side?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we certainly hedged. We're in the high 90s in terms of our investment. And so that's hedged. But given -- you can see the NOI contribution. It's not -- it's real dollars once converted, obviously. So there is risk there. And we're not overly leverag
componenttext: Well, we certainly hedged. We're in the high 90s in terms of our investment. And so that's hedged. But given -- you can see the NOI contribution. It's not -- it's real dollars once converted, obviously. So there is risk there. And we're not overly leveraged. So we'll make some of it on the interest expense as we mark that to dollars on a weighted average quarterly basis. But we've got -- they're extremely profitable. Our debt service ratios are extremely high, so we'll never be able to hedge the profitability of that and never be able to -- we don't want to hedge over our investment because then you will have that run through the P&L every quarter and I don't want to do that. We will have the earnings run through the P&L, but I don't want to go outside of currency hedges that would have to be mark-to-market if we're over-hedged. And so we've always hedged up to our investment, and I think we're in the 90-some-odd percentile. I hope I answered your question.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Partly. So the other question I had was regarding your Seritage JV. And in particular, maybe, Rick, you can talk about -- do you and your partner have similar views on the capital required to redevelop those boxes?
componenttext: Yes. Partly. So the other question I had was regarding your Seritage JV. And in particular, maybe, Rick, you can talk about -- do you and your partner have similar views on the capital required to redevelop those boxes?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Certainly, we have the identical vision as to the potential for those boxes. Each of us are going to have to deal with the funding of that when the time comes through their own sources. But they fully recognize that and we do not perceive that as an issue.

componenttext: We're working with Seritage but also working with Sears because we need to go through the pretty complicated process of downsizing the stores, and that's not a straightforward enterprise.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q2 2016 Simon Property Group's Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call will be recorded. I would now like to introduce you host for today's conference, Mr. Tom Ward, Sen
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q2 2016 Simon Property Group's Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call will be recorded. I would now like to introduce you host for today's conference, Mr. Tom Ward, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katherine. Good morning everyone. Thank you for joining us today. Presenting on today's call is David Simon, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Also on the call are Rick Sokolov, President and Chief Operating Officer; Andy Juster, Chief Fina
componenttext: Thank you, Katherine. Good morning everyone. Thank you for joining us today. Presenting on today's call is David Simon, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Also on the call are Rick Sokolov, President and Chief Operating Officer; Andy Juster, Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Broadwater, Chief Accounting Officer. Before we begin, a quick reminder that statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Safe Harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, and actual results differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. We're to today's press release and in our SEC filings of our detailed discussion of forward-looking statements. Please note that this call includes information that may be accurate only as of today's date. The reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included within the press release and the supplemental information in today's Form 8-K filing. Both the press release and supplemental information are available on our IR website at investors@simon.com. For prepared remarks, I'm pleased to introduce David Simon.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. We had a productive quarter. We're pleased with our strong financial results. We started, completed, opened several significant redevelopment, and new development projects that will further enhance the value of our portfolio. We completed
componenttext:
Okay, thank you. We had a productive quarter. We're pleased with our strong financial results. We started, completed, opened several significant redevelopment, and new development projects that will further enhance the value of our portfolio. We completed the acquisition of the shops at Crystals and we continue to achieve strong operating and financial results and raised our dividend yet again. 
Results in the quarter were highlighted by FFO of $2.63 per share, on a comparable basis, excluding a gain on the sale of marketable securities in the prior-year period, FFO per diluted share increased 9.1% or $0.22, year-over-year for the quarter and for the first 6 months our comparable FFO per diluted share is at 12.1% compared to the prior period. 
Our operating metrics were strong as well as our cash flow, Our mall and premium outlet occupancy was 95.9% with 20 basis point decrease in occupancy from the prior year period is a direct result of due to the new developments in expansions we opened recently. Leasing activity remains healthy. The malls and premium outlets recorded in the releasing spreads of $8.88 per square foot, an increase of 14.8% and a base minimum rent was $50.43, which was up 4.9% compared to last year reflecting the strong retail demand for location and as a reminder, we provided additional new metrics, summarizing the composition of our total portfolio NOI, please see this in the supplemental and the release and for the second quarter of 2016, our total portfolio NOI increased 7.4% and has increased 7.6% year-to-date. 
Our comp NOI increased 3.2% for the quarter and is up 4.1% year-to-date. Total reported retail sales per square foot at our mall and outlets were $6.07 compared to $6.20 in the prior period. 
Let me put a couple of things in perspective, reported retail sales continued to be negatively impacted by the strong dollar, some of our tourist-oriented malls and outlets reported sales per square foot for the malls was down slightly compared to the prior year period primarily due to retailer and the state sales tax implementing sales restrictions, we mentioned this previously, but it is important to reiterate and excluding the anomaly this anomaly, our mall sales per square foot increased for the period, lower tourism spending continues to impact various retail sales at some of our premium outlets, excluding the negative impact of these high-performing tourist oriented centers, retail reporter sales per square foot for the pay outlets was flat, in fact, our traffic in our outlet business thus far is up 2.65% for the year and finally, the second quarter, I would like to point out the retail sales trends improved progressively with June recording the strongest monthly sales performance with total sales volume at comparable properties increasing across all of the property types. 
At the end of the quarter, redevelopment expansion projects were ongoing at 33 properties across the platforms, shares $1.4 billion, we continue to expand, transform, enhance our properties. We completed Stanford Shopping Center and over the next several weeks, we completed a number of transformative and redevelopments including the completion of the connector King of Prussia that will link the court and plaza creating 15 new speciality stores, the comprehensive redevelopment expansion for the fashion center at Pentagon City, the edification of Plaza with a compilation of AC Hotel by Marriott and multifamily residential units were also underway with the transformation of Plaza in McAllen, Texas, where we demolished the box under construction on expansion wing that will accommodate up to 50 specialty stores, 4 junior anchors and exciting new dining Plaza, all of these are to creative returns. We will continue to flow and fuel our profitability and construction includes among others, but not an exhaustive list Woodberry commence, Sawgrass Mills, The Galleria at Houston and on.
Our new development is focused on important markets, where demand is there. During the quarter, we opened a new outlet in Columbus. It's off to a great start. It's been a great partnership with Steve. Our construction continues on our new outlet in Clarksburg, Maryland, which will open in the fourth quarter this year, we also recently broke ground on any outlet Northern Virginia, which will open in mid-2017 we got exciting projects in outside the U.S. We have an outlet under construction in France, South Korea and Canada, all will open in 2017. Also fueling our growth. We also recently started construction in, Malaysia with who is our partner in Malaysia and construction is nearing completion at center in Miami, the centers almost entirely leased with 80 retailers and restaurants coming projects and we're also continuing construction of our high-end retail projects in Fort Worth in the shops. Acquisitions beyond Crystals, we also brought our partner at in Naples and Venice outlets, we now effectively owned 90% of these 2 great assets. We completed turning to capital markets. We completed a successful offerings, EUR 500 million at 125 -- at 1.25% for 9 years. Our liquidity stands at $6 billion and have an industry-leading balance sheet as we hope. We increased the dividend 6.5% year-over-over, 3% from the second quarter and we will pay at least 6 -- 6.50%, which will be 7% over last year. We've also increased the guidance from $10 and $0.77 to $10 and $0.85, this reflects solid performance in the first half in our current view reminder of their, we're very pleased with our performance.

componenttext: Well, look I think it's hard to predict, Craig, it is good to see that the June sales for retailers were up, we're starting to see the stronger dollar anniversary, so it'll have a less impact on the metrics, but anything more importantly, we're seeing other than the anomaly, I talked about in the 1 what the ones stay -- our sales are our fine in the portfolio outside the centers, sales are fine. And we're operating pretty effectively and very slow growth in the U.S. economy. So the anniversary impact is coming up in the next few months. We're starting to see stabilize; but it's very hard to predict.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay and then you extended your presence obviously in Las Vegas with Crystals. I just wondered it would be a different strategy going forward, where you might take shops in 1 direction and Crystals in another?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think there, as you know, Vegas, there is so much tourism there, $50 million visitors a year, each has its own distinct separate marketplace, and obviously pawnshops is bigger and cares to not only a high-end consumer, but also a broader consumer. C
componenttext: No. I think there, as you know, Vegas, there is so much tourism there, $50 million visitors a year, each has its own distinct separate marketplace, and obviously pawnshops is bigger and cares to not only a high-end consumer, but also a broader consumer. Crystals is more luxury oriented, so I think they both have distant markets, will continue to take advantage of those great assets and continue to drive the income up and down. So, I don't think they'll be a huge change in strategy, but continuation of improving operations in both assets.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I look at cash flow growth my friend. So, the other thing that I'd like to point out on that report, we put our entire bucket activity in that number. I don't know what others do, but so if we have as an example, amendments, let's say, we have a retailer
componenttext: I look at cash flow growth my friend. So, the other thing that I'd like to point out on that report, we put our entire bucket activity in that number. I don't know what others do, but so if we have as an example, amendments, let's say, we have a retailer that we have to restructure because we figure well, let's keep them in an operating will ultimately release the space. That amendment goes into that spread out and if there's anything again, I'm pleased with the spread. I think we have so much outperformed on our spread that number of 15% is pretty damn good $8.88 over ending rent for new rent is pretty damn good, but put that aside, if you are looking to grasp on anything, I would say it's somewhat affected by the fact that we had amendments due to some of the retailer situations that we have been dealing with over last 12 months. I'm very pleased with the spread, 9 bucks is a good number in a flat economy. I also -- you look at our comp NOI, which is where focused and cash flow growth. We look at our comp NOI, we haven't just had a couple of years of good numbers. We had a decade of outperformance versus our peer group and as you know, when it comp over, comp over, comp over, comp over comp, that's pretty damn good. So we are very pleased with the number. If you wanted to point something, which I know it is your job to do, I would say it's a worthy amendments, which give you something we're doing in a very slow economic growth environment in the U.S. And we were dealing with that effectively and are still producing very healthy spreads.

componenttext: I guess, the second in terms of recapturing some of the department stores and the JVs that you got with Seritage, can you sort of provide an update on sort of where you stand and opportunity that is the over the next couple of years to maybe recapture some more of boxes?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have continued to work was Seritage and Sears. We've got users identified for our properties such as you mentioned, last quarter. We're working with Sears just on how to downsize their stores and that process is ongoing. I will tell you if you look ove
componenttext: We have continued to work was Seritage and Sears. We've got users identified for our properties such as you mentioned, last quarter. We're working with Sears just on how to downsize their stores and that process is ongoing. I will tell you if you look over the years, we have recaptured 93 department stores and we have done a very effective job of deploying them, if you look at our anchor schedule, we have got ongoing right now. It's an ongoing process. We have a whole team dedicated to it and the good news is we've substantial demand identified in each of our properties, so we know how it would deal with any of the stores that we do get the opportunity to recapture. David talked about La Plaza, which was a Sears store, you got Sears back at college mall. Now the 365 whole food, all small shop and restaurant. We're making money and making the properties better.

componenttext: Well, again our view is to get the market rent that's appropriate for that space. And retail reported -- and I underscore reported retail sales does not necessarily as it had the discussion correlated to what the market rent for that space is. It's more of a function of location, property location in the mall, property type, position in the marketplace and so on. So our focus is getting market rent for each and every space and in doing it in a way that does not put us at risk with sales and what to get paid for that space. And that's not changing now and there's a lot of that is going on the lease in terms of getting credit if they, the sales again this is only case and we're hopefully marketing at the market in over average rent they've got a really outperformed to pay us over rent. But in order to in there reported sales number, and we're negotiating including should know some things to fill from the POS systems and so on. That were included in their reported sales number. Up and again, our focus is more on what the market rent for the spaces as opposed to necessarily what the tenants sales are going to be out of the space.

componenttext: Well in our ownership, again, we've basically 2 ways we operate in Europe. We own properties primarily through McArthurGlen and then we have our ownership interest in Kl√©pierre. componenttextpreview: Well. Look I love being in the spot that we're in. We have no plans. As you know, the sort of publicly out of the big deal business. I reserve the right to change your mind I guess, but if you ask me today when a big deal is business. And I eventually as
componenttext:
Well. Look I love being in the spot that we're in. We have no plans. As you know, the sort of publicly out of the big deal business. I reserve the right to change your mind I guess, but if you ask me today when a big deal is business. And I eventually as you all know, there's going to be cycles in economic world that we live in. And Rick and I are veterans when it comes to real estate, recessions and stuff. So it's always good that being that's spot obviously, and is year we worked really hard to be in that spot, it allows us to grow our dividend, allows us to put capital back into the business that feeds on itself so I think pretty much nothing's changed, Michael business is usually, on the intention of really doing anything with that, other than continuing to relate and I don't think of that cycle. I have no idea. But we're out of the big deal business and we're going to maintain that kind of liquidity and capital primarily to that's the budget we want I think that should be valued by the market. I let you decide whether it is or is not. I don't know. It allows us to reinvest in our portfolio. 
I think the one thing that your talk about physical retail, we talk about physical real estate and I don't care what whether it's in office or hotel or mall or a center. You don't have a good-looking product, you're not -- your customers that will show up. If you've got a apartment building, the you got a office building, you got a mall, you got a center, you got a physical retail store, if it doesn't look good then it does not have the right services in it, doesn't have the right mix, or clientele, you are going somewhere down the road that is a competitive society that we live in and I think our capital allows to try and we don't, we don't execute this the way I think we can continue to be better much better than this but our balance sheet allows us to have a really, really  good-looking physical product under got a lot of work to continue to make it even better, better and better. And I would encourage anyone that is physical real estate missed his physical real estate another example. That's a good job. You got a have -- in just like you're Boeing and you manufactured airplanes, you go to their manufacturing facility, I guarantee you its state-of-the-art beautiful and that is what they do with their cap.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You may have missed this in the outlet business, our traffic is up 2.65% year-to-date even our spend is down in some of the tourist-oriented centers. On the mall, what we are finding is other traffic is stable and interestingly I know a lot of retailers h
componenttext: You may have missed this in the outlet business, our traffic is up 2.65% year-to-date even our spend is down in some of the tourist-oriented centers. On the mall, what we are finding is other traffic is stable and interestingly I know a lot of retailers have reported decreased traffic, what we are seeing is that the consumers are still in our properties, but they are visiting less stores on each visit. I guess, to David's point about the physical presentation. Our retailers need to have stores that present compelling reasons for these consumers to visit them as they're walking on our properties. So there will be less traffic because they are stopping in less stores. But the measures that we look at, the traffic in our property is overall stable.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q2 2016 Simon Property Group Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call will be recorded. I would now like to introduce you host for today's conference, Mr. Tom Ward, S
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q2 2016 Simon Property Group Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
As a reminder, this call will be recorded. 
I would now like to introduce you host for today's conference, Mr. Tom Ward, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Catherine, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. Presenting on today's call is David Simon, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Also on the call are Rick Sokolov, President and Chief Operating Officer; Andy Juster, Chief
componenttext:
Thank you, Catherine, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. Presenting on today's call is David Simon, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Also on the call are Rick Sokolov, President and Chief Operating Officer; Andy Juster, Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Broadwater, Chief Accounting Officer. 
Before we begin, a quick reminder that statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, and actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. We refer you to today's press release and our SEC filings for a detailed discussion of forward-looking statements. Please note that this call includes information that may be accurate only as of today's date. 
Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included within the press release and the supplemental information in today's Form 8-K filing. Both the press release and the supplemental information are available on our IR website at investors.simon.com. 
For our prepared remarks, I'm pleased to introduce David Simon.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. We had a productive quarter. We're pleased with our strong financial results. We started, completed, opened several significant redevelopment and new development projects that will further enhance the value of our portfolio. We completed
componenttext:
Okay, thank you. We had a productive quarter. We're pleased with our strong financial results. We started, completed, opened several significant redevelopment and new development projects that will further enhance the value of our portfolio. We completed the acquisition of The Shops at Crystals, and we continue to achieve strong operating and financial results and raised our dividend yet again. 
Results in the quarter were highlighted by FFO of $2.63 per share on a comparable basis, excluding a gain on the sale of marketable securities. In the prior year period, FFO per diluted share increased 9.1% or $0.22, year-over-year for the quarter. And for the first 6 months, our comparable FFO per diluted share is up 12.1% compared to the prior year period. 
Our operating metrics were strong as well as our cash flow. Our Mall and Premium Outlets occupancy was 95.9%. The 20 basis point decrease in occupancy from the prior year period is a direct result due to the new developments and expansions we opened recently. Leasing activity remains healthy. The Malls and Premium Outlets recorded releasing spreads of $8.88 per square foot, an increase of 14.8%. And our base minimum rent was $50.43, which was up 4.9% compared to last year, reflecting the strong retail demand for our location. 
And as a reminder, we provided additional new metrics, summarizing the composition of our total portfolio NOI. Please see this in the supplemental and the release. And for the second quarter of 2016, our total portfolio NOI increased 7.4% and has increased 7.6% year-to-date.  Our comp NOI increased 3.2% for the quarter and is up 4.1% year-to-date. 
Total reported retail sales per square foot at our mall and outlets were $6.07 compared to $6.20 in the prior year period. 
Let me put a couple of things in perspective, reported retailer sales continued to be negatively impacted by the strong dollar at some of our tourist-oriented malls and outlets. Reported sales per square foot for the malls was down slightly compared to the prior year period, primarily due to a retailer and a state with no sales tax, implementing sales restrictions. We mentioned this previously. It's important to reiterate, and excluding this anomaly, our mall sales per square foot increased for the period. Lower tourism spending continues to impact retail sales at some of our Premium Outlets. Excluding the negative impact of these high-performing tourist-oriented centers, retail reported sales per square foot for the Premium Outlets was flat. And in fact, our traffic in our outlet business, thus far, is up 2.65% for the year. And finally, the second quarter, I'd like to point out that retail sales trends improved progressively with June, recording the strongest monthly sales performance with total sales volume at comparable properties increasing across all of our property types. 
At the end of the quarter, redevelopment expansion projects were ongoing at 33 properties across the platforms. Our share is $1.4 billion. We continue to expand, transform, enhance our properties. We completed Stanford Shopping Center. And over the next several weeks, we'll complete a number of other transformative and redevelopments, including the completion of the connector of King of Prussia that will link the Court and the Plaza, creating 50 new speciality stores; the comprehensive redevelopment expansion to The Fashion Centre at Pentagon City; edification of Phipps Plaza with the completion of AC Hotel by Marriott. And multifamily residential units were also underway with the transformation of Plaza in McAllen, Texas, where we demolished a former Sears box, are under construction on an expansion wing that will accommodate up to 50 specialty stores, junior -- 4 junior anchors and exciting new dining plaza. All of these are accretive returns. We'll continue to flow and fuel our profitability. And construction includes, among others, but not an exhaustive list, Woodbury Common, Sawgrass Mills, The Galleria at Houston and on.
Our new development is focused on important markets where demand is there. During the quarter, we opened a new Tanger outlet in Columbus. It's off to a great start. It's been a great partnership with Steve. Our construction continues on our new outlet in Clarksburg, Maryland, which will open in the fourth quarter this year. We also recently broke ground on a new outlet north of Virginia, which will open in mid-2017. 
We've got exciting projects in -- outside the U.S. We have an outlet under construction in Provence, France; South Korea and Canada. All will open in 2017 also fueling our growth. We also recently started construction in, Kuala Lumpur in Malaysia with Genting, who is our partner in our other Malaysia asset. And construction is nearing completion at Brickell Centre in Miami. The center is almost entirely leased with 80 retailers and restaurants coming to projects, and we're also continuing construction at our high-end retail projects in Fort Worth, anchored by [indiscernible] and The Shops at Clearfork. 
Acquisitions beyond Crystals, we also brought our partner out in our Naples and Venice outlets. So we now effectively own 90% of these 2 great assets. 
We completed turning to capital markets. We completed a successful Euro senior offering, EUR 500 million at 1.25% for 9 years. Our liquidity stands at $6 billion, and we have an industry-leading balance sheet. As we hope you know, we increased our dividend 6.5% year-over-over, 3% from the second quarter. And we'll pay at least 6.50% which will be 7% over last year. We've also increased our guidance from $10.77 to $10.85. This reflects solid performance in the first half. In our current view, the reminder of the year, we are very pleased with our performance.
Questions are available.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, you referenced that there was a pickup in June relative to some of the other months. Do you think that we will start to see the --  annualization of the international shop per pullback? And will that have a less of an impact on the numbers going fo
componenttext: David, you referenced that there was a pickup in June relative to some of the other months. Do you think that we will start to see the --  annualization of the international shop per pullback? And will that have a less of an impact on the numbers going forward?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I think it's hard to predict, Craig. It's good to see the June sales for our retailers were up. We're starting to see the stronger dollar anniversary, so it will have a less impact on the metrics. But I think, more importantly, we're seeing, o
componenttext: Well, look, I think it's hard to predict, Craig. It's good to see the June sales for our retailers were up. We're starting to see the stronger dollar anniversary, so it will have a less impact on the metrics. But I think, more importantly, we're seeing, other than the anomaly I talked about in the one -- with the one stay -- our sales are fine, and the portfolio outside the tourist centers sales are fine. And we're operating pretty effectively in a very slow growth U.S. economy. So the anniversary impact is coming up in the next few months. We're starting to see it stabilize, but it's very hard to predict.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you've extended your presence, obviously, in Las Vegas with Crystals. I just wondered if there would be differing strategies going forward where you might take Forum Shops one direction and Crystals in another?
componenttext: Okay. And then you've extended your presence, obviously, in Las Vegas with Crystals. I just wondered if there would be differing strategies going forward where you might take Forum Shops one direction and Crystals in another?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think there -- as you know, Vegas, there is so much tourism there, I mean, $50 million visitors a year. Each has its own distinct, separate marketplace. They -- obviously, Forum Shops is bigger. It caters to not only a high-end consumer but also a b
componenttext: No. I think there -- as you know, Vegas, there is so much tourism there, I mean, $50 million visitors a year. Each has its own distinct, separate marketplace. They -- obviously, Forum Shops is bigger. It caters to not only a high-end consumer but also a broader consumer. Crystals is more luxury-oriented, so I think they both have distant markets. We'll continue to take advantage of those great assets and continue to drive the income up in both. So I don't think there'll be a huge change in strategy but a continuation of improving operations in both assets.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISA (sic) [ ISI ].
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISA (sic) [ ISI ].

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I know a lot of metrics were fairly positive. I guess the one that just sort of jumped out was sort of the rolling 12 months leasing spread which had a noticeable drop from 17.5% to just under 15%. Is there anything that sort of happened in this qua
componenttext: Look, I know a lot of metrics were fairly positive. I guess the one that just sort of jumped out was sort of the rolling 12 months leasing spread which had a noticeable drop from 17.5% to just under 15%. Is there anything that sort of happened in this quarter that would have pulled that number down? And what do you think is a reasonable expectation going forward?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, again, I respect that everyone loves to focus on operating metrics. As you know me pretty well, Steve, what's the one operating metric that I focus on?
componenttext: Well, look, again, I respect that everyone loves to focus on operating metrics. As you know me pretty well, Steve, what's the one operating metric that I focus on?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Total NOI growth.
componenttext: Total NOI growth.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I look at cash flow growth, my friend, okay? So the other thing that I'd like to point out on that is that we put our entire bucket of activity in that number. I don't know what others do, but -- so if we have, as an example, lease amendments, let's s
componenttext: No, I look at cash flow growth, my friend, okay? So the other thing that I'd like to point out on that is that we put our entire bucket of activity in that number. I don't know what others do, but -- so if we have, as an example, lease amendments, let's say, we have a retailer that we have to restructure because we figure, well, let's keep them in and operating while we'll ultimately release the space. That amendment goes into that spread. And if there is anything -- again, I'm pleased with the spread. I think we have so much outperformed on our spread that, that number of 15% is pretty damn good. $8.88 over ending rent for new rent is pretty damn good. But put that aside, if you are looking to grasp on anything, I would say it's somewhat affected by the fact that we have amendments due to some of the retailer situations that we've been dealing with over the last 12 months. I'm very pleased with the spread. $9 is a good number in a flat economy. I also -- if you look at our comp NOI, which is where -- I'm  focused on cash flow growth. If you look at our comp NOI, we haven't just had a couple of years of good numbers. We've had a decade of outperformance versus our peer group. And as you know, when you comp over a comp over a comp over a comp, that's pretty damn good. So we're very pleased with the number. If you want to point out something, which I know it's your job to do, I would say it's more the amendments, which we view is something that we're doing in a very slow economic growth environment in the U.S. And we're dealing with that effectively, and yet, we're still producing very healthy spreads.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. No, that's helpful. I guess, just secondly, in terms of sort of recapturing some of the department stores and the JVs that you've got with Seritage, can you just sort of provide an update on sort of where you stand and the opportunities that you see
componenttext: Okay. No, that's helpful. I guess, just secondly, in terms of sort of recapturing some of the department stores and the JVs that you've got with Seritage, can you just sort of provide an update on sort of where you stand and the opportunities that you see over the next couple of years to maybe recapture some more boxes?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, Rick Sokolov. We have continued to work with Seritage and Sears. We've got users identified for our properties in Seritage, as we mentioned last quarter. We're working with Sears just on how to downsize their stores, and that process is ongoing. I
componenttext: Steve, Rick Sokolov. We have continued to work with Seritage and Sears. We've got users identified for our properties in Seritage, as we mentioned last quarter. We're working with Sears just on how to downsize their stores, and that process is ongoing. I will tell you, if you look over the years, we've recaptured 93 department stores, and we've done a very effective job of deploying them. If you look at our anchor schedule we have ongoing on right now, it's an ongoing process. We have a whole team dedicated to it. And the good news is we have substantial demand identified in each of our properties, so we know how to deal with any of these stores that we do get the opportunity to recapture. David talked about La Plaza, which was a Sears store. We got a Sears store back at College Mall. Now the mall is arriving 365 Whole Foods, Ulta, small shops and restaurants. We're making money and making the properties better.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paul Morgan with Canaccord.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Morgan with Canaccord.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you look at the development of redevelopment pipeline, you've got $2.1 billion your share of cost of the projects that are going now and almost at on -- and CIP. How should we think about kind of beyond the projects that are kind of in place right now,
componenttext: As you look at the development of redevelopment pipeline, you've got $2.1 billion your share of cost of the projects that are going now and almost at on -- and CIP. How should we think about kind of beyond the projects that are kind of in place right now, what the shadow pipeline looks like? I mean, you've talked about it is a tougher environment. I mean, do you think that this could be -- a peak that would slow going forward as some of these project completions roll off, looking at the next year? Or do you think you've got a shadow pipeline that's going to keep it going at around this level?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me answer it this way. We actually had a meeting yesterday on Sawgrass Mills and Jersey Gardens are just 2 examples that together would be a $500 million to $600 million of redevelopment. So we're very comfortable and confident, Paul, that even
componenttext: Well, let me answer it this way. We actually had a meeting yesterday on Sawgrass Mills and Jersey Gardens are just 2 examples that together would be a $500 million to $600 million of redevelopment. So we're very comfortable and confident, Paul, that even the retail sales have been anemic this year that when you have properties like that, that can be expanded, we have the appropriate amount of demand to make financial -- make the financial consequences very positive for the company, in addition to making those properties even more important. So I don't think we're backing off at all our development and expansion portfolio. The good news is we have such a good number of high-quality assets that we'll continue to find opportunities to expand them. And like I said, I mean, Jersey Gardens and Sawgrass are just 2 simple examples that pop to mind, but that's going to $500 million to $600 million spread and will be -- hopefully delivered in '19-ish, maybe '20-ish, and we'll continue to enhance their marketplace position. So we haven't really changed. I think if we changed anything is -- and I mentioned, I think, the last call or call before that, the -- we put a lot in the system, and that's kind a little bit about -- you saw the 20 basis point. Again, now you might react to 20 basis points decrease in occupancy. I assure you, I do not, okay? I assure you, I do not. But let's -- but we put a lot in the system over the last, whatever, 6 months, primarily in the outlet that we have decided to spread some of those new ground-up developments out a little bit, so that we don't stress the system, and we get the lease-up that we want in those. But our strategy really hasn't changed, and I think we've got plenty of opportunities to continue to enhance our portfolio.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then my other question, you've talked about -- and you provided a list of -- a pretty long list of e-retailers who are looking to open stores in your malls. And I wonder if you have an update on kind of how those rollouts are being received, wh
componenttext: Great. And then my other question, you've talked about -- and you provided a list of -- a pretty long list of e-retailers who are looking to open stores in your malls. And I wonder if you have an update on kind of how those rollouts are being received, whether some of these retailers might be initially opening 3 or 4, this could become 20 or 30 or 40 or are kind of how it's been playing out so far?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll let Rick do his list, and I appreciate you giving him the opportunity because he loves to read his list. I will say this, though, there's so much creative stuff going on with new ideas, new concepts that -- as a simple example, we did a pop-up
componenttext: Well, I'll let Rick do his list, and I appreciate you giving him the opportunity because he loves to read his list. I will say this, though, there's so much creative stuff going on with new ideas, new concepts that -- as a simple example, we did a pop-up store at Woodbury Commons  (sic) [ Common ] with Runway where they actually sold their -- some of their existing inventory, and it had unbelievable success. I'm not going to tell you how much they sold because I don't frankly know if I'm allowed to or whatever. But there is a lot of creativity and a lot of e-retailers that want access to the physical world. And that's just a small example of a unique idea. I actually happen to meet with the CEO and said, "Do a pop-up store at Woodbury, okay?" They did it. They had great success. But now I'll turn it over to Rick to give you the list.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing I would tell you there have been a number of them and we've list them obviously. We talked about [indiscernible], Birchbox, YOGASMOGA. Everyone understands what the dynamics going on with Amazon. We just made a deal with Untuckit. The most
componenttext: The other thing I would tell you there have been a number of them and we've list them obviously. We talked about [indiscernible], Birchbox, YOGASMOGA. Everyone understands what the dynamics going on with Amazon. We just made a deal with Untuckit. The most important aspect of this is that all of these retailers that have Internet presence understand that a bricks-and-mortar presence is an essential part of their strategy. They get much higher conversion in their store. Their customer acquisition is frankly cheaper, and it's something that we're seeing more and more. We're working with, frankly, scores of them to come to our properties. It's certainly going to be a source of growth for us going forward in the out-years.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: And the condition on doing that deal was that Rick could not wear the Untuckit shorts, okay?

componenttext: David, earlier you mentioned lease amendments having a bit of an impact on releasing spreads. Obviously, you've taken a selective approach here. But I just want to ask more generally, are you seeing an increased level of tenants coming to you, looking for lease amendments or would -- and more or less be consistent with the prior couple of years?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's really -- I mean, obviously, there are some high-level news out there with certain retailers, and it's really more of that category than just the person here and the person there. So it's kind of what you've seen. We have less year-to-date bank
componenttext: Well, it's really -- I mean, obviously, there are some high-level news out there with certain retailers, and it's really more of that category than just the person here and the person there. So it's kind of what you've seen. We have less year-to-date bankruptcy than we did last year, but -- so some of that's just rolling through the numbers that we had to deal with last year.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just sticking with leasing here, obviously more sales moving online and not maybe getting captured in your sales or occupancy cost figures. I'm just wondering, are you exploring any changes to your lease structures at all at this point to b
componenttext: Okay. And then just sticking with leasing here, obviously more sales moving online and not maybe getting captured in your sales or occupancy cost figures. I'm just wondering, are you exploring any changes to your lease structures at all at this point to better capture or monitor those sales?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, our view is to get the market rent that's appropriate for that space. And retail reported, and I underscore reported retail sales does not necessarily, as we've had this discussion correlate, to what the market rent for that space is. It's mo
componenttext: Well, again, our view is to get the market rent that's appropriate for that space. And retail reported, and I underscore reported retail sales does not necessarily, as we've had this discussion correlate, to what the market rent for that space is. It's more of a function of location, property location in the mall, property type, position in the marketplace and so on. So our focus is getting market rent for each and every space and in doing it in a way that does not put us at risk with their sales and what we get paid for that space, and that's not changing. Now there is a lot of things going on in the lease in terms of getting credit if they -- the sale -- again, this is only a case when you have overage rent where hopefully marking it to market where overage rent, they've got to really outperform to pay us overage rent. But in order to -- in their reported sales number, we're negotiating, including if it's -- if something is fulfilled from the POS system and so on, that would be included in their reported sales number. But again, our focus is more on what the market rent for that space is as opposed to necessarily what the tenants' sales are going to be out of that space.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Caitlin Burrows with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Caitlin Burrows with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You kind of touched on it earlier, but you guys have 2 ground-up outlets in process now for being developed in Virginia and Maryland and a number of full-price mall expansions going on. So how would you describe the demand for that space, either outlet ve
componenttext: You kind of touched on it earlier, but you guys have 2 ground-up outlets in process now for being developed in Virginia and Maryland and a number of full-price mall expansions going on. So how would you describe the demand for that space, either outlet versus full price or either one versus itself a year or 2 ago?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say to you that the only -- first of all, Clarksburg is going to -- I mean, Columbus, where we partnered with Tanger, is 100% leased, I think. Maybe there's a couple of vacancies. So that was not impacted at all. We've got Clarksburg, where
componenttext: Well, I would say to you that the only -- first of all, Clarksburg is going to -- I mean, Columbus, where we partnered with Tanger, is 100% leased, I think. Maybe there's a couple of vacancies. So that was not impacted at all. We've got Clarksburg, where I think it's going to a great development, opens up in Q4. We've got -- in that case, we are bringing in a very -- what I'd call a high-end mix because we really kind of want that to be ultimately kind of the Woodbury. This an overexaggeration, so don't hold me to it. But we want it to kind of be the fashion -- high-end fashion outlet for the Mid-Atlantic more or less. And so there's -- those retailers sometimes getting them to commit to a new outlet is a little longer process because in a lot of cases, they don't manufacture for it, and it's a function of their full-price strategy. I won't bore you with all the ins and outs of that, but that's going to deliver -- we're going to deliver a great mix. And I think the demand has been excellent, and we're going to hold a couple of spaces just to fill out the kind of the unique mix there. And I'd say that the -- I'd say the outlet demand for new product is good. It's not -- it really hasn't changed. The only thing that I would say for new projects is the luxury-oriented folks are taking a little bit of a more -- little bit of a breather. A lot of that because of what's going on with tourism. So that's a little bit what I'd call softer than it might have been a year or plus ago but not material as evidenced by the mix that we're producing at Brickell, which is going to be a great project that the 3 partners have worked very hard to produce.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then it seems like over the past couple of years some kind of bright spots at the mall in terms of who's been opening and who's been doing well that you and your peers have talked about includes fast fashion and restaurants. So just wondering if
componenttext: Okay. And then it seems like over the past couple of years some kind of bright spots at the mall in terms of who's been opening and who's been doing well that you and your peers have talked about includes fast fashion and restaurants. So just wondering if those types of mall tenants are still generally looking to have larger stores or more stores or just generally doing maybe better than the other apparel-type guys?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Rick. We are continuing to very much focus on the addition of restaurants and food throughout the portfolios. There's still a considerable amount of demand. Just to let you know, last 5 years, we got to almost 200 restaurants across our portfolio.
componenttext: This is Rick. We are continuing to very much focus on the addition of restaurants and food throughout the portfolios. There's still a considerable amount of demand. Just to let you know, last 5 years, we got to almost 200 restaurants across our portfolio. We had 25 last year. We have another 53 scheduled to open this year and next year. And so they are also finding substantially increased productivity when they are associated with our projects as opposed to a freestanding pack. And that has certainly helped that demand. That in terms of the other tenants you alluded to, certainly the international tenants are continuing to grow. We've got -- we've already talked to e-retailers. We've got brand extensions. There is still considerable demand for our space, and we're doing okay.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as Rick said, the restaurant demand is great.
componenttext: And as Rick said, the restaurant demand is great.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just a few questions here, David. First, you guys obviously disclosed your rent spreads and those sort of stats and say -- but can you give a little bit more color on sort of same-center ancillary income growth. As you guys have rolled out that program
componenttext: So just a few questions here, David. First, you guys obviously disclosed your rent spreads and those sort of stats and say -- but can you give a little bit more color on sort of same-center ancillary income growth. As you guys have rolled out that program, is it still growing? Is the growth really coming from rolling out more and more ancillary at each mall? Or is it more of -- or that maybe of maxed-out individual malls, so that more of the growth is coming as you roll out different programs to new malls and outlets, too?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would -- let me give you just a big picture. I would say it's actually in the -- when you ancillary a lot of -- put kind of our SPV effort to aside, we've actually reduced it pretty significantly in our high-end portfolio. So we've cleaned out wha
componenttext: Well, I would -- let me give you just a big picture. I would say it's actually in the -- when you ancillary a lot of -- put kind of our SPV effort to aside, we've actually reduced it pretty significantly in our high-end portfolio. So we've cleaned out what I'll call a lot of stuff. And again, we think that's the right thing to do. It's maybe -- it's clearly costing us some income. But at the end of the day, we think it's the right thing to do. So if you look at kind of our high-end portfolio, we've cleaned a lot of stuff out, and we're very sensitive to creating the environment where those retailers can do the most business. So if anything, we suffered delusion. And you know how I love cash flow, but I've got to do -- I've got to balance that. So we've actually reduced that, and that's hurt us over the last few quarters. And the Outlet business, it's probably picked up a little bit. So there again, there is an answer for everything, but I think we've done a -- we put in some what I'd call veteran mall people to kind of run that business over the last couple of years, and they've actually done a pretty nice job increasing those ancillary. So up in outlet, down in the high-end malls pretty significantly, and I think the rest of it's kind of commiserate with the marketplace.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you -- but as far as the reduction of the high-end malls, can you just give sort of a magnitude, like a  percentage, like if you had -- was it a 5% reduction to overall ancillary income? 10% when you look in the aggregate of what you guys do?
componenttext: Can you -- but as far as the reduction of the high-end malls, can you just give sort of a magnitude, like a  percentage, like if you had -- was it a 5% reduction to overall ancillary income? 10% when you look in the aggregate of what you guys do?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Second question is just looking at your European portfolio, obviously a lot of unfortunate tragic events that have occurred. What has been the impact at the retail level? Have -- is it people are going forward and life goes on or hav
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Second question is just looking at your European portfolio, obviously a lot of unfortunate tragic events that have occurred. What has been the impact at the retail level? Have -- is it people are going forward and life goes on or have you seen any impact to either tenant openings or sales or anything like that or maybe just increased expenses from things that have to be done?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in our ownership interest -- again, we have basically 2 ways we operate in Europe. We own properties primarily through McArthurGlen, and then we have our ownership interest in Kl√©pierre. Kl√©pierre is public company. I think they reported today, an
componenttext: Well, in our ownership interest -- again, we have basically 2 ways we operate in Europe. We own properties primarily through McArthurGlen, and then we have our ownership interest in Kl√©pierre. Kl√©pierre is public company. I think they reported today, and their numbers have been pretty good. Look at retail sales. The only country that I'd say, which is not insignificant there, that's a little bit underperforming but still up is in France. And I don't know that I'd necessarily equate that to the -- what's happened terrorist-wise. But just France's general economy is a little bit behind, say, Italy, Spain and the Netherlands and Scandinavia and so on. So -- but that -- all of that data is out there for you. I think their business is actually pretty decent, and they chug along. We see no impact whatsoever on our McArthurGlen portfolio. Look, they have their assets are, in a lot of cases, tourist oriented. And so if tourism changes, they'll have that -- you'll see that impact a little bit, but we haven't seen it. So far, their numbers have been pretty impressive year-to-date.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Christy McElroy with Citi.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the department store recapture. To what extent do you think we'll continue to see department store closings? And how do you think about sort of the economics of redeveloping a box like that in terms of the cost per square foot of the r
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the department store recapture. To what extent do you think we'll continue to see department store closings? And how do you think about sort of the economics of redeveloping a box like that in terms of the cost per square foot of the redevelopment and then looking at sort of the rents that you can get on new tenants versus the in-place rents of the department stores currently there?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Christy, first of all, all of our recapture activity has been included in all of our development yield table. So I think we said that we work it out and we get comparable yields that we can get in the rest of our development projects. There's a range from
componenttext: Christy, first of all, all of our recapture activity has been included in all of our development yield table. So I think we said that we work it out and we get comparable yields that we can get in the rest of our development projects. There's a range from a high single-digit, low double-digit. We've identified the boxes, and every deal is unique as to what the cost would be for redeveloping the box, if it's a full-box user, are we splitting the box and how the box is configured. But all of those yields are in, and the most important thing is that we've been able to produce our result, and we've had a great deal of activity in that sectors, witnessed by all the anchors that we continue to add across the company.
