headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Simon Property Group Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. And now I'll turn the conference over to your host, Tom W
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Simon Property Group Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
And now I'll turn the conference over to your host, Tom Ward, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. Please begin.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tyrone. Good morning, and welcome to Simon Property Group's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Presenting on today's call is David Simon, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Also on the call are Rick Sokolov, President and Chief Ope
componenttext:
Thank you, Tyrone. Good morning, and welcome to Simon Property Group's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Presenting on today's call is David Simon, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Also on the call are Rick Sokolov, President and Chief Operating Officer; Andy Juster, Chief Financial Officer; and Steve Broadwater, Chief Accounting Officer.  
Before we begin, a quick reminder that statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, and actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. We refer you to today's press release and our SEC filings for a detailed discussion of forward-looking statements.
Please note that this call includes information that may be accurate only as of today's date. Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included within the press release and the supplemental information in today's Form 8-K filing.
Both the press release and the supplemental information are available on our IR website at investors.simon.com.
For our prepared remarks, I'm pleased to introduce, David Simon.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Good morning. We had a very productive quarter. We started, completed, opened, several significant redevelopment and transformation projects that will further enhance the value of our portfolio, and we continued to achieve strong financial results.
componenttext:
Okay. Good morning. We had a very productive quarter. We started, completed, opened, several significant redevelopment and transformation projects that will further enhance the value of our portfolio, and we continued to achieve strong financial results. 
Before I get to some of the highlights of the quarter, I would like to quickly highlight our outlook for the remainder of the year. Based on our performance year-to-date, our current view of the quarter, we are once again increasing our full year 2016 FFO per share guidance range to $10.85 to $10.87, which was higher than our original guidance of $10.70 to $10.80.
Our increased range also reflects a potential charge of $0.08 per share, with respect to our likely decision to postpone the construction of the Copley Residential Tower due to the rapidly rising construction cost and our beginning concerns around supply and demand in the Boston residential market.
Work will continue on redeveloping and modernizing the existing retail space at the center as well as the development of the Southwest corridor, which will create a new entrance to Copley. We expect this work will enhance the shopping experience for our guests and retailers and further strengthen our position in the heart of Boston, and will be completed by summer of '17. Assuming we make the decision to postpone, it does not foreclose the opportunity to build the tower in the future as market conditions warrant. 
Now let me turn to the quarter, FFO per share was $2.70, an increase of 6.3% compared to the prior year. For the first 9 months, our comparable FFO per diluted share is up, 10.1% compared to the prior year period. 
We continued to see strong demand for space across our portfolio, combined occupancy for our malls and Premium Outlets, ended the quarter at 96.3%, an increase of 20 basis points compared to the prior year. 
Leasing activity remains solid. The Mall and Premium Outlets recorded re-leasing spreads of $6.71 per share -- per foot, an increase of 10.9%, given our high occupancy level of above 96%, the remaining space we are leasing, while not as well located, continues to produce healthy re-leasing spreads. 
And as a reminder, we include lease amendments for the restructuring of leases where we choose to work with retailers in certain situations, pre-or post bankruptcy, such as PacSun. 
Base minimum rent was $50.76, up 4.5% compared to last year, reflecting growth in our rents, our occupancy cost of 13% as well.
Now just as everyone knows, my focus is on cash flow growth, and I believe this is the most important metric for the investment community to focus on. 
Our total portfolio NOI increased 7.3% year-to-date and 6.6% for the quarter -- third quarter. To put our growth rate in perspective, the 7.3% year-to-date growth is more than $300 million. Our result to date keep us on track for our full year guidance of total NOI growth of more than 6% for our portfolio.
On the NOI overview schedule included in our supplemental filed this morning, you can see the various platforms of growth that contribute to our portfolio NOI. 
The diversity of sources fueling our NOI growth is unique to Simon. Comp NOI increased 3.5% year-to-date and 2.2% for the quarter. Our comp NOI results are affected by declines in overage rent due solely to the impact of the strong dollar on our tourists, spending at our centers are active and re -- extensive redevelopment pipeline across all our property platforms as we relocate, reconfigure a significant number of tenants in order to enhance the future of retail and dining experiences at our properties and our decision to strategically moderate the marketing and specialty income in the common areas of our highly -- of our very high-end portfolio.
Total retail sales per square foot at our malls and Premium Outlets were $604 compared to $616 in the prior year period. Reported retailers centers continue to be impacted by this strong dollar at some of our tourist-oriented malls and Premium Outlets. Reported retailer sales at our centers outside of our tourist-oriented centers are stable. 
Reported sales also include initial dilution from newly-opened space. And importantly, we're beginning to anniversary some of this decline. As you can see, our recent sequential quarters Q2 to Q3 of our sales productivity is basically flat.
The end of the third quarter, redevelopment and expansion projects were ongoing at 32 properties across all of our platforms. Our share approximately 1.1. We opened as you know, King of Prussia, which connected the Plaza and the Court. We finished Fashion Center at Pentagon city. We started the expansion of Allen Premium Outlets of 120,000 square feet in North Texas and in the next several weeks, we opened 60,000 square-foot expansion at the outlets at Orange. And we, also, are opening our expansion in Venice, Italy, with our partner McArthurGlen of 67,000 square feet. So we continue to add value across the portfolio. 
Now on new developments, just so happens, tomorrow, we're opening Clarksburg Premium Outlets, the center will offer great retail line up. We expect it to cater to the whole Washington, D.C. metro area. We currently have 5, that's right, 5 outlets under construction, one in Norfolk, Virginia, 4 in the international markets, including France, South Korea, Malaysia and Canada. All of these will open in '17. 
And even though we're opening a new outlet next week, the week after, we're actually opening Brickell City Centre in Miami. It's anchored by Sachs. It's got a great retail line up with great partners in Swire and the Whitman Family and is part of a landmark mixed-use development, we look forward to managing the retail and as a reminder, we're only investing in the retail and construction continues on the full price development of Fort Worth, The Shops at Clearfork anchored by Neiman Marcus opening in the fall of '17. And these 8 new projects represent around $765 million of spend our share. 
Now let me turn to A√©ropostale. We are pleased to have partnered with GGP, Authentic Brands Group, Hilco, and Gordon Brothers to acquire A√©ropostale. In addition to the existing management team, the ABG group will add significant operating experience to A√©ro. We have a long track record of making smart capital allocation decisions. And after reviewing this opportunity with our partners, we believe this investment proved to be yet another opportunity for our company. 
It's also important to keep this investment in perspective. You've all seen the gross number of $243 million. I want you to understand that $188 million of that is inventory being purchased by Hilco and Gordon Brothers, and not by our buying group. Our initial investment is approximately $55 million by the group, of which our share is $33 million, including working capital. And the only reason we decided to make this investment is because we believe we can make money. 
If our model is right, we think we're buying this company at 1x to 2x EBITDA, with future growth opportunities ahead of it. And we continue to believe that this will be an astute investment, and for some of you who don't know ABG, it is backed by Leonard Green, which has been a significant important investor in retail throughout years, Whole Foods, Neiman Marcus, J.Crew, just to name a handful. 
Also during the quarter, we acquired our partner's interest with McArthurGlen in our 2 outlets in Maples and Venice. We continue to focus on our industry-leading balance sheet. We completed a number of secured financings during the quarter. We continue to lower our borrowing cost, increase our debt maturity, term our current liquidity at $6.5 billion. 
And finally, on our dividend, in 2016, we will have paid $6.50. That's an increase of 7.4% compared to $6.05 that we paid last year. That's a lot. I'm ready for your questions.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question is from Caitlin Burrows of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question is from Caitlin Burrows of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask on the leasing spread topic. I know you touched on it. And it's been a popular point of conversation here. Since it's a trailing 12-month number, are the results we're seeing now in terms of lease spread just a pull forward, an extens
componenttext: I just wanted to ask on the leasing spread topic. I know you touched on it. And it's been a popular point of conversation here. Since it's a trailing 12-month number, are the results we're seeing now in terms of lease spread just a pull forward, an extension of something that happened to slowdown in 2Q? Or did the third quarter slow too, realizing that it does include lease amendments?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have had -- look, let's just put this number in perspective, number one. We do include lease amendments and that's having the biggest impact of the growth slowing. Yet, if you look at our average base rent, you can see we're doing new initial ter
componenttext: Well, we have had -- look, let's just put this number in perspective, number one. We do include lease amendments and that's having the biggest impact of the growth slowing. Yet, if you look at our average base rent, you can see we're doing new initial terms. We're doing very well. And some of the expiring leases also are a little bit -- expiring at a little bit higher level. Now our investors know that over a long period of time, we've always felt like the $5 to $6 spread was kind of always in our -- always part of our model. In fact, as we've done a tremendous job of outperforming that, but the long-term we've always kind of felt that, that $5 or $6 spread is kind of where we think the market is. We had a couple of years of significant outperformance, but we are not backing off our inherent value that we have in our leases as they roll over. And we're just getting back to kind of more of a normal environment. But for us, I don't know about our peers, but for us, we include these amendments and the bottom line is, that is having some impact on the leasing spread. But that $6 to $7 is maintaining itself, and that's kind of what we've told investors, year after year after year and we feel very good about that.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, just also you mentioned that right now, as you lease space given their high occupancy, the remaining space might not be as well-located. So I guess, my question is since you have that high occupancy, what are kind of your thoughts behind m
componenttext: Okay. And then, just also you mentioned that right now, as you lease space given their high occupancy, the remaining space might not be as well-located. So I guess, my question is since you have that high occupancy, what are kind of your thoughts behind making these lease amendments and working with companies, such as you've pointed out, PacSun?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's literally a case-by-case analysis. I think, we're as sophisticated as anybody. I think -- and A√©ropostale is a great example of our ability to analyze what the right trade is in these deals. And in some cases, were going to take the space back
componenttext: Well, it's literally a case-by-case analysis. I think, we're as sophisticated as anybody. I think -- and A√©ropostale is a great example of our ability to analyze what the right trade is in these deals. And in some cases, were going to take the space back. In other cases, we're going to help the retailer go through the hard time. And it's really a case-by-case -- it's a case-by-case analysis. But there is nobody I think, in our industry that more sophisticated in our ability to kind of maneuver through those situations. So it's case-by-case. Anything can happen. Well, sometimes it will work, sometimes we'll get the space back and certainly in the A√©ro case, we thought the opportunity was even more exciting to just buy the retailer and make a vertical investment that the entire S&P community is doing. Amazon makes vertical investments. The cable industry makes vertical investments. And again, I would encourage -- we decided to make vertical investments when we decided to franchise Starbucks locations 2, 3 years ago. That's the nature of our company, is that we're going to be nimble, we're going to -- we have the right judgment when to make a deal with the retailer, when not; when to make vertical investments, when not; when to go to Europe. We are not win to pull the plug on Copley and we are not -- that's why we're in the position that we are in today. And each and every case will be one by one. And I do appreciate and I hope I'm right with you, Caitlin, I do appreciate you waiting to write until we have our call. I do think that's important, because of the reason we have these calls is for not every -- there's not every scenario where you can understand the nuances about what's going on in our business. So I do appreciate your patience to hear our story and then obviously, you write whatever you want to write.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Steve Sakwa of Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Next question is from Steve Sakwa of Evercore ISI.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, is there a way for you to try and help separate out for us the impact of these amendments on the numbers? Meaning, PacSun and Arrow were having as big an impact as they are. Is there a way to sort of strip them out and give us a sense for kind of
componenttext: I guess, is there a way for you to try and help separate out for us the impact of these amendments on the numbers? Meaning, PacSun and Arrow were having as big an impact as they are. Is there a way to sort of strip them out and give us a sense for kind of what the remaining lease spreads look like? Because obviously, these are kind of the biggest number that people are focusing on and if these 2 leases or tenants are having a disproportionate impact, it might help to separate out those figures for us.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't -- look, our business, Steve -- I hear you. If we need to, we might. But the fact is you got to look at our business in totality. You can't look at it on one operating metric or not. Because what I would ask you to look at is -- why, let's t
componenttext: Well, I don't -- look, our business, Steve -- I hear you. If we need to, we might. But the fact is you got to look at our business in totality. You can't look at it on one operating metric or not. Because what I would ask you to look at is -- why, let's talk about the 3 [ph] -- we have grown our portfolio NOI, $300 million, year-to-date. Let's talk about that. Do you want to talk about that? That, to me, is more material than any one operating statistic, quarter-by-quarter. So yes, we could -- we can slice and dice this anyway, but if we can spend more time talking about how does a company grow its portfolio NOI 3 -- there are many REITs that don't have $300 million of NOI, yet we grew that in 9 months. So I would rather talk about that is more material than the fluctuations that have -- that are occurring with operating metrics. We could talk about sales. Sales are impacted by the fact that we have great properties in tourist markets and the strong dollar. That doesn't mean that's going to last forever. But again, there's this high desire to make that be-all, end-all of these metrics. And again, our numbers are clean. The results are the results. We can't speak to anybody else how they do it, but I, as I said to you, if you want my opinion on what's important, it's the $300 million NOI growth. If you don't want it, I got it. But that's what I'm focused on.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I get it. And I don't think people are dismissing your ability to deploy capital whether it's through development or expansions, but clearly, there's been more pressure on the mall business. I just think anything you can do to dissuade [ph] the fears
componenttext: No, I get it. And I don't think people are dismissing your ability to deploy capital whether it's through development or expansions, but clearly, there's been more pressure on the mall business. I just think anything you can do to dissuade [ph] the fears about the internal growth prospects going forward and perhaps it's just that a $6 to $7 spread on a roughly $60 or $61 expiring rents mean that normalized leasing spread should be 10% and maybe that's what we're going to head to. There's a new normal in the business. That's okay, I think, people are just trying to get comfort with that.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, that's a good point. So let's talk about that. I mentioned that a little bit in the first question. I think -- if you ask our investor group, we would have told them for 15, 20 years, that our re-leasing spreads are $5 or $6 a foot [ph] , o
componenttext: Well, I think, that's a good point. So let's talk about that. I mentioned that a little bit in the first question. I think -- if you ask our investor group, we would have told them for 15, 20 years, that our re-leasing spreads are $5 or $6 a foot [ph] , okay? We have had a long period of outperformance on that. We've gotten better what we've done. Also as of recent so we don't have to be for you. And you're right, we may be going back to kind of what we have promised our investor base for a long period of time. And the outperformance, I don't think from our standpoint, we ever guarantee the outperformance from how we look at re-leasing spreads. We always said, "Look, it's $5 or $6, one year it might be $8, one year it might be $4," but that's kind of what we see the long-term trend. And I still feel comfortable that, that's the basis. Now it's no surprise that retail generally, has come under pressure. Lots of different reasons, which we could go into, but let's -- on this you want to, it's not -- but the fact is -- and we are impacted, as I said, to you before, by our general GDP growth. And our -- today, our retail generally is -- there's no inflation, and our nominal GDP growth is 1.5%, yet we're growing our comp [indiscernible] -- I mean, and if nominal GDP -- there is some inflations, so maybe real GDP growth is, I don't know, 50 basis points. We're still growing our business with no inflation in our particular business at 3.5% comp NOI. That's not bad. It's not 4% [ph] plus that we did last year or the year before, but it's still in the scheme of being able to grow our business. That's not bad. And we are -- I'm not defensive about it. I mean, that's kind of what I think, we should expect when we have essentially real GDP growth of 1%. Maybe a little bit less, maybe a little bit more. And I think, that's what we've got to put in perspective.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Christy McElroy of Citi.
componenttext: Next question is from Christy McElroy of Citi.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael Bilerman here for Christy. To dividend, I wonder if you could talk a little bit about putting capital into your stock. Last year, you had bought, I think, it was like $350 [ph] million at about $1.80 [ph] . Obviously, the stock was some of the sel
componenttext: Michael Bilerman here for Christy. To dividend, I wonder if you could talk a little bit about putting capital into your stock. Last year, you had bought, I think, it was like $350 [ph] million at about $1.80 [ph] . Obviously, the stock was some of the sell off as well as some of the retail headlines have come off, 20%. We spent a lot of time talking about something you spent $30 million on, and I was wondering if you got a $2 billion share repurchase program, how you feel about putting money into your stock?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I think, at the end of the day, the best thing we can do is invest in our product, okay? Because the stock will go up and will go down, but by investing in our product -- and I think, unfortunately what I was a number of retailers they have no
componenttext: Well, look, I think, at the end of the day, the best thing we can do is invest in our product, okay? Because the stock will go up and will go down, but by investing in our product -- and I think, unfortunately what I was a number of retailers they have not invested in their product, okay? And -- or they taste the holy grail of Internet sales to that detrimental what they should be doing with their physical product is still people want to go physical shopping. And when they go physical shopping, you've got to have a nice physical environment. So we have spent a lot of years wanting to invest in our physical product. And I think, that's our #1 focus, continues to be, we're well through that. The good news is that been contrarian on that. We started that in '10 [ph] . And as you know, we are finishing projects. It's not just talking about projects, but it's finishing a lot of projects. So I think, as that winds down, then the opportunity to buy stock  back is always there. And I just don't think it's a high priority, but that can change depending upon kind of where the world is and what the stock does, but I think, my job is -- the #1 job I should be doing is investing and making my product better. And that's my #1 focus.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you talked in your opening comments about your dealmaking over years and always taking a proper risk reward it and thinking about the capital committed to whether it's a project or whether it's a venture investment. As you think about investing in the
componenttext: And you talked in your opening comments about your dealmaking over years and always taking a proper risk reward it and thinking about the capital committed to whether it's a project or whether it's a venture investment. As you think about investing in the Aero [ph] , putting $30 million, where  -- is there a house limit that you'd want to have in no sorts of investments relative to the whole? And where would it sit within the Simon organization? Is it more within the venture side? Or is there another sort of area, I don't know, if it's in the Dabid Simon bucket? I don't know, where does it sit within the organization?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look even though I'm older, I can always learn new things. And I have learned a lot actually, going through the Arrow deal. That's -- it's -- we're going to act as an investor. We're going to give strategic direction as a board member. Authentic Bra
componenttext: Well, look even though I'm older, I can always learn new things. And I have learned a lot actually, going through the Arrow deal. That's -- it's -- we're going to act as an investor. We're going to give strategic direction as a board member. Authentic Brands, I encourage you to look at the brands in the history of that company. They've done a great job of -- they are brand builders. They are entrepreneurs. So we are not going to be running the business. We're going to help strategically like we did. It will be -- but -- so I've got my IT guys helping with their IT systems. We've got our lawyers helping with their license agreements. So it -- we have a lot we can bring to the table. And that's what makes us unique. And -- but it's not going to overwhelm anybody's particular time. They've got a good management team, and with our strategic help, I think, we'll continue to make that profitable. And look, based on the numbers I think, it's going to be a compelling investment. But it's not without risk. I mean, it is -- there are -- there is risk out there, whenever you make a pension or a life investment but I can't think of a better team between Gordon Brothers, Hilco [ph] , ABG [indiscernible] to all put our collective judgment to bear to make this a profitable investment. I don't think, going back to your first question, I don't think this is going to be the wave of the future. I mean, AT&T -- I mentioned vertical because I just tried to put certain things outside of real estate in perspective, okay? So AT&T was buying, going vertical. They're spending $100 billion. I go vertical, I spend $33 billion -- million not billion, $33 million. And again, I'm not comparing -- I'm just trying to put these things in perspective, I'm not comparing our business to AT&T or anybody else. Amazon, what's made Amazon great? Is that they've had the latitude to grow critical. They've gone vertical. They've gone content, do gun this tradition, they've gone retail. And that maybe the future of corporate America is that you're not going to pigeonhole -- if we want to just talk about leasing a Sears box that we get back, that's okay, for some companies but that's not what we are about. So again, there's no -- we have no bucket -- it's not going to take away from what we're doing. My #1 priority is to make our product better anyway that we can, technology digital investments look and feel better retailers, different mix and our redevelopment, whatever. However, that transpires and making a vertical investments you're there like an overwhelm us. But I won the latitude to and I think, the investment community should want us to. And at the end of today, if our underwriting numbers are right and there is risk, we are buying a business that ought to be valued at 6x EBITDA, and we're buying at 1x to 2x. And I think, that's a pretty good trade. But we've got to -- we're not there yet, and that's the goal, but that's what we're trying to accomplish.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Christy. Just a bigger picture, the consortium has talked about a 300 to 400 store base count for Aeropostale [ph] . There's been a lot of talk about store count rationalization among national retailers are generally and how many stores need to serve
componenttext: It's Christy. Just a bigger picture, the consortium has talked about a 300 to 400 store base count for Aeropostale [ph] . There's been a lot of talk about store count rationalization among national retailers are generally and how many stores need to serve their customers in their market today, why is that the right number of stores for retailer like Aeropostale? And what does that imply for your view of the need for other retailers specially now that you're looking at this issues through that A√©ropostale lens?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's very --  I think you've pointed out something that's very unique is that we are getting the lands at the much granular level on retail. So it's very interesting. Sourcing -- look, there are 5 or 6 things that really make a retailer click. Sourc
componenttext: Well, it's very --  I think you've pointed out something that's very unique is that we are getting the lands at the much granular level on retail. So it's very interesting. Sourcing -- look, there are 5 or 6 things that really make a retailer click. Sourcing obviously, expense, store expense, the merchandise, the quality of the, the packaging, all of the stub that I think, at the end of today are going to make a better real estate owners. But that remains to be seen. Arrow, I'm probably getting get in trouble for this, but since I like you, I'm going to tell you. Right now, we're looking at around 500 stores in the U.S. It's kind of the model. And based upon -- we expect everyone of those stores to be profitable. So it's a much bigger business than we initially when in an investment -- we were thinking we could justify our investment at the much lower store base, the fact of the matter is we found out there's a lot more store profitability of their than we thought. So it's going to be around 500, give or take. But I think, store closings, it is -- the pressure for retailers to invest in the Internet to close stores from their investment community is great. I would question whether that's the right strategy, because some of these stores are very profitable, yet they feel like the headline closing stores is the answer and then all of these investment into the Internet is going to pay all these dividends. Fact of the matter is, there is a really healthy physical store environment and mall environment. And I think, all of us can't lose sight of that and that's where we should be investing. So I do think there will be more pressure on store closings. Unfortunately, over our history, we are pros to that I don't need to remind you that the top 10 tenants that we went public with in '93, no longer exist in 2016 and we will be able to deal with it. It's much easier to deal with it when you have a quality portfolio that we do across all of the retail platform that we have. But it's the -- it's the soup of the day. And so I don't think it needs to be 300 or 400 or 500. I think there are a lot of profitable stores that retailers are feeling the pressure. They have got to do something and I would like to invest in their stores, that's something like I would like them to do. But I don't always win that argument. So were equipped to handle that. That's what we do. And -- but I expect that trend probably to continue. Now what we did say when we started this year, our occupancy is up. So put that, Christy. It is up -- so put that in perspective. We also set our bankruptcy store closings would be down in '16. It is down. We had much greater in '15, and we basically more or less leased all of the bankruptcies that we got back in '15 in a flat to tough retail environment. And I think, everybody needs to put that in perspective, okay? So but that doesn't mean were doing cartwheels here. It is we're grinding, were as good as it gets when it comes to grading and that's the environment that has presented to us and we'll have to deal with it.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jeff Spector of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jeff Spector of Bank of America.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm also here with Greg Schmidt. I guess David, if we could just talk a little bit more about the current environment, let's say it continues, it persist through '17, even '18, how should we think about these rent amendments? How are you thinking about it
componenttext: I'm also here with Greg Schmidt. I guess David, if we could just talk a little bit more about the current environment, let's say it continues, it persist through '17, even '18, how should we think about these rent amendments? How are you thinking about it when you're letting out your budget for next year? Is this just something that we should get used to as we transition here as the retailers invest more money in their stores, we see more stores closing? How should we think about that?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, again, it's a retail-by-retail perspective. We are seeing a stabilization in our sales business. If you want to go focus on retail sales, quarter -- Q2 over Q3 is basically flat. And if you take out tourism, you take out 1 retailer that's h
componenttext: Well, I think, again, it's a retail-by-retail perspective. We are seeing a stabilization in our sales business. If you want to go focus on retail sales, quarter -- Q2 over Q3 is basically flat. And if you take out tourism, you take out 1 retailer that's had decreases in sales, it's actually up. So we are not like -- there is no huge concern here, but we just -- we are a product of the overall U.S. economy, and Jeff, what's the real GDP growth? You tell me. So in that environment, what do you think it is? The real one? Real GDP growth, what would Merrill's got a bunch of smart people, what would they say of this?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're saying around that 1%, 1.5%.
componenttext: I think we're saying around that 1%, 1.5%.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're good, I'm not that good, but I got a lot of people around me that are good. That's a constraint. So but it is what it is, we'll sort it through, and I do think, in that kind of environment, we're going to have certain deals where we will go back and
componenttext: We're good, I'm not that good, but I got a lot of people around me that are good. That's a constraint. So but it is what it is, we'll sort it through, and I do think, in that kind of environment, we're going to have certain deals where we will go back and then we're going to have a lot of other deals, frankly, we're going to take the space back. And my moods change in a little bit, that maybe we're better off taking the space back. I think, we did play ball a little bit more with the bankruptcies in '15 and the year early, '16, and that's showing up in the lease spread. And I'm thinking, sales are okay, stabilizing, maybe the world gets over all of these stuff that's going out there. Maybe we stabilize, a lot of people feel like we're headed for growth. So maybe we take more space back. But we've kept the buildings full, as evidenced by the occupancy, there is a trade-off. We're on our target for comp NOI increase. So it's not all that bad. So just put in perspective, '17 will transpire, and we'll do a combination sometimes -- sometimes we'll play ball, other times we're going to take the space back and it's all a function of retail-by-retail decisions, space-by-space, retailer-by-retailer.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think, Craig has one question.
componenttext: And I think, Craig has one question.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I could do a little bit of a pivot here. Looking at your new developments for the outlets, 4 of the 5 projects are international, can we expect to see continued good growth in new projects on the international scale? And then maybe more specifically
componenttext: Maybe I could do a little bit of a pivot here. Looking at your new developments for the outlets, 4 of the 5 projects are international, can we expect to see continued good growth in new projects on the international scale? And then maybe more specifically, with your longer-term plans are with McArthurGlen?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we just had a meeting -- I had a meeting with our partner Friday, last Friday. And the business is very good, very solid. Provence is opening spring of next year, which will be fantastic. We are very close on getting the potential to build in Norman
componenttext: Well, we just had a meeting -- I had a meeting with our partner Friday, last Friday. And the business is very good, very solid. Provence is opening spring of next year, which will be fantastic. We are very close on getting the potential to build in Normandy, which we think will be a great -- which will basically cover the Western Parisian market. That could be fantastic. We've got a couple of acquisitions that we are working on, extensions that we are working on. So -- it's all good there, it's been -- of the teams are working well together. Couldn't be more pleased with the investment, and I think, it's -- for it, it's kind of business as usual development -- new development growth, very pleased, just that we've been able to create that partnership and create that relationship, going forward. In Asia, the team is working in a couple of other markets that I'm hopeful, over time, that we'll be able to build the Premium Outlet product there. We've got a couple of big expansions in the works. Katamba [ph] is an example that could be a landmark extension. So that business -- we're not slowing by any stretch of imagination, internationally, in our outlet business, either with McArthurGlen or with our Asian partners.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Alexander Goldfarb of Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Next question is from Alexander Goldfarb of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's earnings season, life's great. So just a few questions here. Let me start with an easier one before I ask one on the favorite same-store topic. Here in New York, obviously, a lot of -- sorry, the demand for street retail has gone down, so a lot of va
componenttext: It's earnings season, life's great. So just a few questions here. Let me start with an easier one before I ask one on the favorite same-store topic. Here in New York, obviously, a lot of -- sorry, the demand for street retail has gone down, so a lot of vacant spaces, articles about global brands weakening, rethinking their street retail needs especially with where rents are and store profitability. Have you seen -- as those brands have dialed back, have you seen them -- I don't want to say shift back, but have you seen more interest in going in malls where they are profitable? Or from your perspective, they've always been running street retail, their investment there, separate from their decision to open up in a very -- in malls?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think there is a generic answer to that. I think, it's brand-by-brand. And generally on the luxury side of those brands, their business is actually -- there are starting to anniversary some of the strong dollar stuff, and we are obviously -- obvio
componenttext: I don't think there is a generic answer to that. I think, it's brand-by-brand. And generally on the luxury side of those brands, their business is actually -- there are starting to anniversary some of the strong dollar stuff, and we are obviously -- obviously, we are as well. They -- and I meet with a lot of the folks. I mean, there are certainly some brands here and there that are pulling back, but I'd say generally -- and you're starting to see the numbers like from that are posted recently. Their business is good, pretty good. I think, New York is -- this is a novice because we have no street retail, but New York is a little confusing to them because you got Fifth [ph] , you got Madison, you got downtown, you've got different -- you got new development, you got West 57th Street. So they're all trying to sort it out. I think, in the -- in our business it hasn't changed and if anything, I'd say the mood is generally better than it was 6 months ago. If you want a generic statement, and I think, New York city itself is just different, because they're all tried to figure out where they need to be given what's going on in New York. But we don't have a dog in that hunt. And I think, Brickell is going to be -- I mean, we have also delay with the hurricane and -- because it really technically wasn't a hurricane I'm not really sure. But Brickell, I think, is going to be a lot of the retailers will open in the first quarter of next year, but I think that mix there is really going to be great, cool. I think the Saks store is going to be great. And the demand on that just continue to pick up, right, Rick? Over month after month, and I think, that's a good indication that if you have a good product, if you have a good scheme, retailers are coming. Rick you want to comment on Brickell?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Brickell is certainly going to show that there's going to be a great mix of designers, food, international retailers. And we're -- right now we are 91% leased. And as David said, the opening is going to take place over. We're going to have a big
componenttext: I think, Brickell is certainly going to show that there's going to be a great mix of designers, food, international retailers. And we're -- right now we are 91% leased. And as David said, the opening is going to take place over. We're going to have a big slug over the next few weeks and another big slug over the first quarter of next year. The only other thing I would say to you is that we are seeing at the international retailers like H&M accelerating their focus in our properties in the United States, because there is demand to grow in this market. And we are seeing that.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just say, we've got just to finish the whole thought and you can ask me if it's  on comp NOI, it's not a tough question. I'm going to tell you exactly what I'm thinking.
componenttext: And I would just say, we've got just to finish the whole thought and you can ask me if it's  on comp NOI, it's not a tough question. I'm going to tell you exactly what I'm thinking.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: You don't know the question yet, David.
componenttext: You don't know the question yet, David.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bring it on.
componenttext: Bring it on.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: We don't give our questions in advance.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. Thank you, that's what I like about you, Alex. So but just to finish the luxury, people that would populate street retail in New York, we say a luxury, we're -- not that it's easy but we're making progress with Clearfork, and that's in Fort Wo
componenttext: Okay, good. Thank you, that's what I like about you, Alex. So but just to finish the luxury, people that would populate street retail in New York, we say a luxury, we're -- not that it's easy but we're making progress with Clearfork, and that's in Fort Worth, Texas. We're going to have those kinds of brands, not a lot of them, but the right ones. We opened King of Prussia, within -- in the connection and a lot of those are opening, but the results from those high end brands have been fantastic. So that part of our business is different. I think, it's interesting. It's actually starting to do better than maybe what you're seeing in whatever is being talked about in New York Street retail. But I really -- I don't know, I don't really have a dog in that hunt.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay then the second question is, it sounded like you said that the bankruptcy and the issues really peaked last year and that you guys are more accommodated with retails trying to restructure and therefore, teams like this year we're seeing the impact in
componenttext: Okay then the second question is, it sounded like you said that the bankruptcy and the issues really peaked last year and that you guys are more accommodated with retails trying to restructure and therefore, teams like this year we're seeing the impact in the same-store metrics at the same time, I think, you said that the tourism impacts strong dollars is anniversarying. So it almost those like next year we should expect same-store metrics to get a positive comp as these trens sort of anniversary. So is that fair or as you guys look at your leasing for next year, we should -- still should see some of these impact, whether it's on re-leasing spreads or same-store NOI, et cetera, should we still see that in '17? Or is '17 going to be a little bit better because these stuff anniversarys [ph] ?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, our the big unknown is just what's going on and the overall all you have to do -- and you're a smart financial guy, look at our P&L. You could see put the leasing spreads aside, put all these other stuff aside, I mean, the reality is, the comp NOI i
componenttext: Look, our the big unknown is just what's going on and the overall all you have to do -- and you're a smart financial guy, look at our P&L. You could see put the leasing spreads aside, put all these other stuff aside, I mean, the reality is, the comp NOI is really a function of our overage rent. It's right there on the financial statement, okay? It's down. You can't help it. I mean, it's really a function of the factor that we've got is great tourist centers were suffering from that impact but I do think that's a long-term impact. But it's starting to anniversary, and it shouldn't continue to get worse, okay? But Alex, you could get worse, because no one knows what's going to happen with the dollar. The international tourist market is volatile, at best we live in an uncertain time. But I think, we're doing -- to deliver this 3.5 [ph] and deliver over 6 [ph] portfolio growth is, I think, is reasonably good. It's not great, but it's reasonably good, given some of the constraints that we're dealing with that are a little bit out of our control, a little bit. We're going to take responsibility for a lot of those stuff, but a little bit out of control. So I think, it's too early to tell you on '17. Unfortunately, I say this, because it starts not next week, the week after, Rick, when our property budgets?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, week after.
componenttext: Yes, week after.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Week after, where we'll go one-by-one, space-by-space. And we'll report back early next year what our view of that is. And it's a little -- there's a little more volatility in being able -- the standard deviations probably a little bit higher than it used
componenttext: Week after, where we'll go one-by-one, space-by-space. And we'll report back early next year what our view of that is. And it's a little -- there's a little more volatility in being able -- the standard deviations probably a little bit higher than it used to be, just because of the environment that we have -- that we are operating in.

componenttext: And just confirming, 8th [ph] year taking an $0.08 charge that's in guidance [indiscernible]

componenttext: I'm glad you asked that. And the answer is yes. That is in guidance. So that -- if we have not taken that charge, our guidance would be up another $0.08.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow on that, so that will be $0.13, I mean, is there anything you can point to as a driver of kind of that kind of guidance increase in late October?
componenttext: Just to follow on that, so that will be $0.13, I mean, is there anything you can point to as a driver of kind of that kind of guidance increase in late October?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, generally -- what we're producing the results we want to produce. So you know, I know the operating metrics are not perfect, and that we're not going to deny that. I mean -- but we totaled at the beginning of the year, this is the plan, 3.5 [ph] 6 [
componenttext: Well, generally -- what we're producing the results we want to produce. So you know, I know the operating metrics are not perfect, and that we're not going to deny that. I mean -- but we totaled at the beginning of the year, this is the plan, 3.5 [ph] 6 [ph] and we're producing a little bit better on that front overall, and that's where it rolls up to. And so we are very, very cautious on we have made a final decision on that, but I think, it's likely that we're going to do that. But we've got -- I've got to run through the board and we -- but I want the market to know that, that may be off the table going forward at least for the time being. And we could -- look, we have could've kept it in our books and waited, but you know what, I think, the right thing to do it if we in fact, decide to do it, we'll be to take that ahead.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you mentioned in terms of the same store number not just the PacSun but then also I think, you said intentionally kind of reducing the specialty leasing program in the common area at some of your high-end malls, I mean, is that a -- is that
componenttext: Okay. And then you mentioned in terms of the same store number not just the PacSun but then also I think, you said intentionally kind of reducing the specialty leasing program in the common area at some of your high-end malls, I mean, is that a -- is that a material impact in kind of what sort of the thought process behind that? And kind of maybe if you have a number you've given us in the past, kind of what that program is as a percent of NOI?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, it's material in that it does affect the comp number. The comps would be higher, had we not chosen. But look, part of what we have to do is listen to our clients. Our clients, to some degree especially in certain areas of the mall, very con
componenttext: Well, I think, it's material in that it does affect the comp number. The comps would be higher, had we not chosen. But look, part of what we have to do is listen to our clients. Our clients, to some degree especially in certain areas of the mall, very concerned about that. So we want to be receptive. We've got competition and some of these markets that we've got to be responsive to, and we just think it's the right thing to do. We did a lot of research on the consumer. And so we really there's care, but on the other hand, we have to -- when it comes to the property business, we've got to listen to our IE the retailers, et cetera, and we obviously have to be listening to the consumers, they do bridge here, but in this case, we want to be a sensitive to decline as we can. And some are very sensitive to us, and we don't want to keep that from bringing the right mix into the -- into some of these centers, and that has hurt us over the years, we've thinned out in the very high end properties.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just going to say has this strategy been kind of accelerating recently, that's why you mentioned in terms of same store number this quarter? Is it on going over the past period of time?
componenttext: I was just going to say has this strategy been kind of accelerating recently, that's why you mentioned in terms of same store number this quarter? Is it on going over the past period of time?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, it's been -- look, we didn't really do it last year because a lot of these projects were in a state of development, but it's clearly been beginning -- it's clearly been throughout '17. And remember, this stuff builds. So it has more of a -- as yo
componenttext: I think, it's been -- look, we didn't really do it last year because a lot of these projects were in a state of development, but it's clearly been beginning -- it's clearly been throughout '17. And remember, this stuff builds. So it has more of a -- as you go later in the year, that's more of a backend impact. Okay? So it kind of builds, it's less important in Q1 and Q2, just because the seasonality of our business.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just last question. I appreciate all the color on the Arrow economics. And just wanted to ask, I mean, there have been dozens of similar bankruptcies over the years and you probably could have opportunities to do something similar then. Ma
componenttext: Great. And then just last question. I appreciate all the color on the Arrow economics. And just wanted to ask, I mean, there have been dozens of similar bankruptcies over the years and you probably could have opportunities to do something similar then. Maybe you could point anything outside just the economics of it that makes you think differently about this? And then just going forward, I mean, I know you have kind of the mac review about vertical integration, but anything more kind of your narrow business-driven, where you didn't do this for years and now it looks interesting?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, it's a very good question. And I would say this. I think, as we've got to know Authentic Brand Group, we now have -- for us to have done this without their involvement on how to stabilize and then grow the brand, I mean, that would -- I mig
componenttext: Well, I think, it's a very good question. And I would say this. I think, as we've got to know Authentic Brand Group, we now have -- for us to have done this without their involvement on how to stabilize and then grow the brand, I mean, that would -- I might have that expertise couple of years from now maybe, I say I, I say we do get it but maybe, you'll never know. And I think, having -- and it's very interesting. I've been talking to authentic brands over -- for a year about an other brands that might fit into this model that we've -- are creating, but they didn't come to fruition for whatever reasons. But I think, we finally -- we had over this last year been able to develop kind of an operating model and platform. They're at great of brand building, having general growth as part of that and their ability to bring their real estate and thoughtfulness to the table, in terms of how you operate a business was very helpful. So the -- having the liquidation angle solved with PilCo [ph] and Gordon Brothers was critical. So -- it was really -- in a nutshell, it was really because the partners were able to do it. The partners brought so much to the table, that this was the right deal. If it were just us on our own, I'm not -- I'd be the first to tell you, I don't know that we would do it. We've done Starbuck franchise -- franchises, but that's -- we did by the way, and I encourage everybody that goes to Del Amo, go to Pink's Hot Dogs, that's owned by your company, Simon Property Group. I'm so excited about that franchise that we own. Great hotdogs, it's an institution. That's -- we've got a small group of kind of runs that business. This is a little bit out of the ordinary. And I would say simply put, we have this partnership that was able to navigate all of the complexities of this. And so I think, that's the important determinate why we did this a versus not doing others.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the partners see it as not necessarily just the one off but something that could be replicated?
componenttext: And the partners see it as not necessarily just the one off but something that could be replicated?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Yes, but let's -- we've got walk the call before we run.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Rich Hill of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question is from Rich Hill of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to just ask a quick question about the lease amendments, maybe in the context of your broader portfolio of malls. You have obviously, the luxury of seeing across the productivity spectrum. So when we are thinking about lease amendments and maybe yo
componenttext: Wanted to just ask a quick question about the lease amendments, maybe in the context of your broader portfolio of malls. You have obviously, the luxury of seeing across the productivity spectrum. So when we are thinking about lease amendments and maybe your higher-quality malls, is it maybe the case that some of these tenants are paying above market rents to get into the best quality malls and therefore, you might still be incentivized to make a lease amendment, maybe reduce their rent but recognizing it still in a pretty attractive rent overall? Is that the right way to think about it? And then maybe if you could provide some color, if any, about how you're seeing lease amendments on malls doing $700 a square foot versus maybe those doing $350? But I do appreciate that it's mall-to-mall.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, that's -- it's certainly we have some of those cases. But it really is mall-by-mall, space-by-space, and what the retailer relationship is and what we think the retailer future is. I wish there were simple straightforward answer, but there i
componenttext: Well, I mean, that's -- it's certainly we have some of those cases. But it really is mall-by-mall, space-by-space, and what the retailer relationship is and what we think the retailer future is. I wish there were simple straightforward answer, but there is not. We tried to use our business judgment in figure out what the right is. It's also due we want to be conservative or do we want to be aggressive, what's our mood of the future? As you know, last year, we had a lot of bankruptcies, and we gave direction that like, okay. We're starting to change our attitude a little bit. I can tell you that it's going to be a complete reversal we try to make the right judgment call. Now I would tell you lease amendments like anything else. They -- once you do it for one retailer, don't hit yourself, you hear about it, it goes everywhere else. Part of our job is to contain that. And -- but we've experienced this before. We did do it in other economic times, and again, our business is fine, but it's not -- we're trying to be accommodating. But we could shift our strategy pretty quickly, and we try to evaluate one by one. Rick, do you want to add anything to it?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say to it most important consideration for me to realize is these lease amendments are not forever. One of our considerations is do we have a better replacement tenant but that tenant won't be ready to open for a year? Or where it is in the projec
componenttext: I would say to it most important consideration for me to realize is these lease amendments are not forever. One of our considerations is do we have a better replacement tenant but that tenant won't be ready to open for a year? Or where it is in the project and what is the project. So all of those factors come into play as to how we want to deal with a specific room and how we price the room and how we interface with that tenant. And the only other point I would make is that -- and it gets lost some times, but today, our portfolio has never been stronger, never been better. Physical condition, never had a better mix of small shop tenants, better mix of boxes, better mix of restaurants, better set of amenity. So we are on a continual basis taking share, and that's our focus, to make our properties as compelling as they can be, and that's help us in dealing with the things that you been talking about.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And again, the business we are 96.3% occupied. And as an example, Macy's announced 100 store closings. They're closing -- Macy's is leaving one of our malls. They're leaving one of our malls, we think, in a very small mall that has basically no financial
componenttext: And again, the business we are 96.3% occupied. And as an example, Macy's announced 100 store closings. They're closing -- Macy's is leaving one of our malls. They're leaving one of our malls, we think, in a very small mall that has basically no financial impact to us at the end of the day. So there is this narrative and the mood but the fact of the matter is, go back to 7.3% NOI growth, that's $300 million, let's put it all in perspective, okay?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Floris Van Dijkum of Boenning.
componenttext: Our next question is from Floris Van Dijkum of Boenning.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could I -- could you give a brief update on what's happening with your Seritage JV?
componenttext: Could I -- could you give a brief update on what's happening with your Seritage JV?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are basically in the same position that we articulated in our last earnings call. We have identified users for our boxes. We have plans for our boxes. We are not going to grow with that redevelopment. And so we have a firm understanding of our returns
componenttext: We are basically in the same position that we articulated in our last earnings call. We have identified users for our boxes. We have plans for our boxes. We are not going to grow with that redevelopment. And so we have a firm understanding of our returns and the costs of downsize from this year stores. There are conversations going on right now regarding those costs, and as soon as we have a clear understanding of that, we are in a position to proceed to try the next and skewed on some of those redevelopments.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that would include the Primark at Parisian  [ph] mall?
componenttext: And that would include the Primark at Parisian  [ph] mall?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is independent. That is proceeding as the addition of Primark at South Shore [ph] and a portion Sears, which is not in Seritage. The Primark lease at Burlington was existing at the time we did our joint venture, and that is proceeding.
componenttext: That is independent. That is proceeding as the addition of Primark at South Shore [ph] and a portion Sears, which is not in Seritage. The Primark lease at Burlington was existing at the time we did our joint venture, and that is proceeding.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, question for you. In terms of how sustainable do you -- you're talking about this 6.6% to 7% NOI growth, but if you put that in perspective, you do that for a decade, you've doubled NOI. I mean, is that realistic for a $100 billion [ph] company?
componenttext: David, question for you. In terms of how sustainable do you -- you're talking about this 6.6% to 7% NOI growth, but if you put that in perspective, you do that for a decade, you've doubled NOI. I mean, is that realistic for a $100 billion [ph] company?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are working to achieve that, okay? I can't -- I'm not that clear of wanting to look out that far.
componenttext: We are working to achieve that, okay? I can't -- I'm not that clear of wanting to look out that far.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: But do you see anything near term that's going to break that streak?
componenttext: But do you see anything near term that's going to break that streak?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well I think, we're going to lead our industry in portfolio NOI growth, but we've done it for so long, I don't see any reason why we can't continue.
componenttext: Well I think, we're going to lead our industry in portfolio NOI growth, but we've done it for so long, I don't see any reason why we can't continue.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Next question is from Michael Mueller of JPMorgan.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess going back at Arrow for a second. You discussed this as being more of an opportunistic investment, but out of curiosity, when you first thought about it and got into it, was it more a defensive play to control store closings? Or how did you look a
componenttext: I guess going back at Arrow for a second. You discussed this as being more of an opportunistic investment, but out of curiosity, when you first thought about it and got into it, was it more a defensive play to control store closings? Or how did you look at it, initially?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not at all. As I said, in my opening comments, I mean, no one would put new money into it. The business that we didn't think would have an exciting future. And that's evidenced by kind of the group that we have bought the company. So we certainly get the
componenttext: Not at all. As I said, in my opening comments, I mean, no one would put new money into it. The business that we didn't think would have an exciting future. And that's evidenced by kind of the group that we have bought the company. So we certainly get the benefit of paying rent, but that's not a reason to invest in the business. We can -- we could release those spaces, and that's not affect in putting new money into an investment.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And on the outlet side, could you talk about international expansion? Can you just talk about the U.S. and what the opportunities are that you see over the next 5 years, 10 years? Just what does that pipeline look like?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: In our outlet business?
componenttext: In our outlet business?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes outlets.
componenttext: Yes outlets.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- the pace may not be as hectic as we've done over the last 3 or 4 years, but Norfork, we open next year, we're going to actually start another outlet in the spring of this year, spring of '17 in a very good growing market. We've got another 1 un
componenttext: I think -- the pace may not be as hectic as we've done over the last 3 or 4 years, but Norfork, we open next year, we're going to actually start another outlet in the spring of this year, spring of '17 in a very good growing market. We've got another 1 under serious examination. So I don't think it will be as maybe as active as we've had over the last 2 or 3 years, but we'll selectively do some stuff 1 -- at least 1 a year on average, maybe 2, where we've got some I think, some unique opportunities. We're also very focused on expanding with the Allan [ph] deal -- adding a 120,000 square foot to a center that does, I don't know, $600 plus a foot, in the outlet business is very attractive. So there's a lot to do with the investor portfolio as well.

componenttext: Just wanted to go back to something you just said on just a minute ago. As you deal with retailers like Aeropostale and PacSun, and go through lease negotiations, how do you really contain that risk that somehow leverage doesn't move more towards retailers that might be in trouble or that might come back to you and try similar deals going forward?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said, when this happens, you get -- we do get a -- it does tend to spread on the other hand, it's very simple, so we're not going to do it. So that changes the dynamics pretty quickly. So, again we don't -- this is a space by space, retailer by
componenttext: Well, as I said, when this happens, you get -- we do get a -- it does tend to spread on the other hand, it's very simple, so we're not going to do it. So that changes the dynamics pretty quickly. So, again we don't -- this is a space by space, retailer by retailer decision. It's not pervasive throughout. But -- again, I explained to you a rationale why we did it, '15, '16. But it's something that we'll -- we evaluate everyday with every retailer. And my instinct is that we could be changing how we dealt with kind of the '15, '16 stuff already. But will -- it will be a case-by-case basis.

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just going back to your development pipeline, you have about $3.5 billion worth of projects. Just given that some of those projects -- are a lot of them probably at a time where maybe the view of the retail environment will be a little bit diffe
componenttext: Okay. And just going back to your development pipeline, you have about $3.5 billion worth of projects. Just given that some of those projects -- are a lot of them probably at a time where maybe the view of the retail environment will be a little bit different, how should we think about the overall arch of capital department?  Is it reasonable to expect that number to come down going forward?

headline: Simon Property Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, there is nothing in our redevelopment that we are not doing other than potentially Copley and Copley was -- I mean, I would encourage everybody to study what's going on in construction costs and what's going on in the supply and demand there. We did
componenttext: Look, there is nothing in our redevelopment that we are not doing other than potentially Copley and Copley was -- I mean, I would encourage everybody to study what's going on in construction costs and what's going on in the supply and demand there. We did not want to be -- unfortunately, the build there is longer than it should be, because of the nature of how we have to reinforce the structure. And we spend a lot on it to get approvals and to make sure we had the engineering to do it. But the reality is when we start to see the construction cost, it just not the right time to do it with all the supply and the cost there. We don't see that anywhere else in the portfolio. So we've got a lot of very interesting stuff to do beyond what we are doing now and like I said, we've done some really good work in the field and King of Prussia being part of the Brickell, Clearfork, we've got plans to expand fashion Valley and I can go through the whole list, but that part of the business is an innovated. Because we think that investing in our real estate is what we should do for a living, and that's not changing. But we do have to worry about supply and demand. And I'm not worried about supply and demand in our retail portfolio. In the case of Copley, I got nervous about. Be the first to admit.
